name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 31 May 2018.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I would like, at the beginning of this House, to send a message of solidarity with Guatemala. We've seen terrible images of the erupting volcano. The drama began last week and the volcano is still active. Guatemalan authorities have announced that the death toll exceeds one hundred people. The number of missing is also very high. Nearly two million people have been affected by the volcano, which is more than 10% of the country's total population. I know Copernicus satellites are being used to assist in rescues. Humanitarian aid is also coming from the European Union; but above all, I would like to express, on behalf of the European Parliament, our affection and support for the people of Guatemala at this difficult time.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: On 31 May, the Court of the European Union annulled two decisions of the Bureau of the European Parliament, which imposed a sanction on MEP Korwin-Mikke for statements made during two plenary sessions. At the session on 7 June 2016, the honourable Member described migrants as 'human rubbish that does not want to work'. At the session of 1 March 2017, during the debate on the gender pay gap, Mr Korwin-Mikke argued 'that women should earn less than men because they are weaker, smaller and less intelligent'. I respect court decisions. However, I firmly believe that it is my duty, always, to penalise those who claim that women are inferior beings. (Applause) I will never give up defending equality between women and men. I owe it to all the women who, at the cost of enormous sacrifices, have won their rights over the centuries and who, despite this, still remain victims of discrimination and violence in every country of the European Union. I have asked Parliament's Legal Service to consider appealing against the decision to the Court of Justice. We shall be discussing this again this evening in the Bureau.  (Applause) I owe it to my mother, who is no longer there, but also to my wife, my daughter and all of you.

name: Antonio TAJANI

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I guess we are all still under the impression of the G7 controversial messages, decisions and developments, and therefore I think we should stick to the historical rules, to the facts. Therefore, I would propose, on behalf of our Group, that we change the title of the debate on Tuesday to the new version. I will read it out: ‘Georgia’s breakaway regions ten years after the war with Russia’. This is much closer to the facts which happened – and what are the facts? How we can deal with the responsibility of the European Union in contributing to finding solutions to this very complicated and controversial situation should be the matter of the debate.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the security situation in Georgia has frequently been debated in the Subcommittee on Security and Defence. We were usually in agreement that the territories of South Ossetia and Abkhazia were not voluntarily breaking away from Georgia, but that the situation in these regions is due to high pressure from their neighbour, namely the Russian Federation. Georgia did not declare war on those territories or any other, particularly Russia. It was a Russian invasion of the integral territories of Georgia. Therefore I am against. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We now come to the amendments for Wednesday. name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to say that I am proud to be part of a Parliament which, last December, was able to find a large majority to reform the Dublin system. I think that if the solutions we have adopted here become a reality, we would not be in the situation we are in today - a situation where a ship with more than 600 people on board, including more than 130 miners, is tossed from one place to another in the Mediterranean because two countries have decided to close their ports to it, in violation of their legal obligations. So I understand the frustration of Italy, Malta, Greece, Bulgaria or Spain, which too often the Dublin rule leaves alone to face the challenge of immigration. Obviously, we can't leave them alone. Having said that, it does not excuse what is happening and we think we need to put this item on the agenda.  We have tried to find a compromise. I understand that our Socialist colleagues, not wanting to dissociate themselves from the Maltese Prime Minister, would like us not to talk about the closure of ports, which I do not have a problem with, even if that is the trigger, then we could rephrase the title. I will say it in English because that is the title we found: 'Council and Commission statement on humanitarian emergencies in the Mediterranean and solidarity in the European Union.' We could agree with this compromise title, I hope that he can find a large majority in this House.

I think the scandal is so great that we cannot wait for a separate debate on Wednesday afternoon. (Applause)

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on Werner Langen's report, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 648/2012 as regards the obligation to compensate, suspension of the clearing obligation, reporting requirements, risk mitigation techniques for OTC derivative contracts not offset by a central counterparty, registration and supervision of trade repositories and requirements for trade repositories (COM(2017)0208 - C8-0147/2017 - 2017/0090(COD)) (A8-0181/2018).

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I have a loud voice, but I would still be grateful if the noise was a little smaller. (The President called for calm in the Chamber) Today, ten years after the start of the financial market crisis and five years after the adoption of EMIR, the European Market Infrastructure Regulation, we are discussing proposals made by the Commission to adapt this important instrument to deal with the financial market crisis and mitigate risks to the needs and experience of recent years. EMIR has been in force since 2012. The last international agreement with the US under the Dodd-Frank Act entered into force on 17 February 2017, so we have similar equivalent rules here worldwide. The adjustment is due to experience, particularly with smaller market participants, with non-financial market participants, who naturally have a much lower risk than the major players in the market, and that is why we have simplified the reporting requirements. The Commission has proposed this, we have modified it somewhat. We have given the reporting obligations clear liability. We want to largely free up non-financial small counterparties, and we wanted to iron out inconsistencies in the first regulation. The competent Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs adopted the proposal on the basis of the negotiated compromises with the other groups by 46 votes to 5 with 4 abstentions. This is a very good basis for negotiating with the Council after Parliament's vote. At the same time, I would also like to thank three presidencies: the Estonian, which started discussing the proposal relatively early, the Bulgarian one, which has developed it further, and I hope that we will be able to complete the negotiations in a few rounds with the Austrian Presidency of the Council, thereby adopting a modern set of rules capable of significantly improving the risk reduction in the area of derivatives. As a reminder, in 2009, the nominal volume of global derivatives was USD 720 trillion; that was exactly twelve times the world's national product of all 7.5 billion people. The volume has fallen slightly, and above all the risk values have improved significantly. We have made rules and proposals that go beyond those of the Commission, which the committee approved. We have also discussed a really contentious point in Parliament, which we will also discuss further with the Council: this is the extension of the exemption from the clearing obligation for pension funds that use OTC derivatives to reduce investment risks. We have now extended the derogation four times so far, and the Commission has proposed another three years and, at the end of the day, two years. Bearing in mind that the volume of pension funds in the European Union is at least EUR 3.6 million, that is a huge stake. I am very grateful to the Commissioner, Vice-President Dombrovskis, for having set up a round table on this issue to hold the debate, a round table that will come up with proposals for solutions. And Parliament wants to extend these deadlines, at least not a permanent exception. That is why, Mr Dombrovskis, we are extremely grateful. I have read the minutes of the first round, and the stakeholders have also said there: yes, we believe that a solution is feasible. With this in mind, I would like to thank all those involved – the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission, the players in the market – for their good contributions. I hope that this amendment can be adopted tomorrow with a clear vote in plenary.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadows for the excellent work they put into preparing the committee report. Your vote tomorrow concerns the first of the two proposals we put forward on the European Market Infrastructure Regulation, or EMIR, in 2017. This proposal is about simplifying EMIR, reducing costs and burdens where possible without calling into question the core objectives of EMIR: financial stability, risk mitigation and transparency. The proposal is part of the Commission’s Regulatory Fitness and Performance programme. It emphasises the need for cost reduction and a simplification. The need to revise some of EMIR’s requirements became evident from the responses we got to the Commission’s general call for evidence on financial services legislation in 2016. Our proposal is technical but important. Its savings potential is big. The estimated cost reductions are up to EUR 6.9 billion in fixed or one-off costs, and up to EUR 2.6 billion in annual operational costs. Our proposal includes a more professional clearing obligation for non-financial firms: it exempts the smallest financial counterparties from the clearing obligation altogether; it introduces a new mechanism to suspend clearing in exceptional circumstances; it incentivises clearing and improves access to it; and it simplifies reporting requirements, in particular for businesses without compromising the quality of data. Companies, market participants, regulators and supervisors all agree on the need for this proposal and largely support it. I am very pleased that the debate and the vote takes place now as the adoption of the proposal is urgent. As Mr Langen outlined, pension funds currently benefit from an exemption from central clearing which expires very soon. Without legislative change this exemption cannot continue, but we still need this exemption for a limited time. While the market has progressed, it has not yet adopted viable solutions for pension funds to centrally clear their derivatives. In recent months the Commission has brought together all stakeholders to discuss progress towards a clearing solution for pension funds, and last week I hosted a high-level meeting with those stakeholders and I was happy that some of you joined us for this. I was glad to see that industry stakeholders all committed to design and implement a solution. We need a bit of time to put this commitment into practice, but let me be clear, we are not giving a carte blanche. Progress during this extended exemption period must be monitored, and the Commission will set up a monitoring group for this purpose. Finally, let me highlight again that the purpose of this proposal is to introduce some targeted amendments to simplify and to make EMIR requirements more proportionate. But these amendments need to uphold the fundamental objectives of EMIR. For example, when it comes to reducing requirements to report or exchange bilateral margins for derivatives: if we go too far, supervisors will no longer be able to supervise and monitor over-the-counter derivatives and mitigate systemic risks. We must keep in mind that this piece of legislation is one of the cornerstones of the new system we put in place after the crisis in agreement with the G20. It’s our collective responsibility to ensure that it remains effective.

name: Brian HAYES
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I want to congratulate my colleague, Mr Werner Langen, for his report. It is a very sensible approach and there is strong support in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) for this report. In particular, the rapporteur’s proposal to extend the intra-group exemption to a global basis and to introduce full, single-sided reporting for non-financial corporations is welcomed. This will significantly reduce costs for most small companies, which can then be reinvested in the real economy. When the Commission published their proposal last May, the idea was to eliminate disproportionate costs and burdens on small companies and to simplify rules without compromising financial stability. The Parliament has taken this approach and has stuck to the argument produced by the Commission. By applying single—sided reporting as opposed to the current dual-sided regime, it would bring Europe in line with other jurisdictions and make the EU more attractive destination for corporate treasury functions, which is an important aspect. Parliament’s position reduces the proposed three-plus—two—year exemption for pension funds to comply with the clearing obligations to two—plus—one—year exemption, with very small pension funds exempted. I understand the compromises that were reached on behalf of my colleague and his colleagues in ECON, but at the end of the day we do need to be careful about this. Whether European pension funds will be able to comply with the requirements over a very short period of time is a serious issue. I was the rapporteur for the IORP II Directive; I am aware that pension funds are fundamentally different to other financial entities when it comes to clearing, as they have a long—term investment profile and low liquidity needs. We really need to be sure that pension funds will be able to manage a new clearing obligation in such a short space of time, especially given the difficult position that many pension funds find themselves in right now with the low interest rate environment and the difficulty of making returns for existing members and beneficiaries. We have to find a solution to this; I like the idea of a round table. The exemption cannot continue forever but we need to be cautious in how we respond to the pension issue.

name: Jakob von WEIZSÄCKER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would first like to thank the rapporteur, Werner Langen, and all shadow rapporteurs for the excellent spirit of cooperation that produced a good report, building on a sensible Commission proposal to streamline EMIR in a number of areas. It has been our priority, in working on this file, to safeguard financial stability and to expand central clearing, while allowing some simplification in areas where reduction of requirements has little influence on systemic risk and helps to reduce cost. A notable improvement is the introduction of a specific clearing threshold for financial counterparties. However, perhaps most notable in this report – and it has been mentioned by previous speakers – are the credible arrangements to bring pension funds into the scope of the clearing obligation somewhat sooner than was envisaged, against the backdrop of a number of extensions that have already taken place. Here I am particularly grateful to the Vice—President for having invited me, among others, to the round table that you organised with stakeholders – not least in view of the realism of the two-plus-one solution that we are envisaging.  So I am confident that it is absolutely possible to implement the necessary steps, especially for bigger pension funds, within the timeframes that we have put forward. Indeed, on 16 May a large majority in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) voted for those particular deadlines. This measure stands to improve financial stability – that is bringing in pension funds and the safety of pensions – while giving all stakeholders enough time to prepare. I am looking forward to continuing our work in the forthcoming trialogues and would be delighted if this House were to vote with a large majority to enter into interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The decision to include EMIR in REFIT has succeeded in concluding that in some areas EMIR will generate disproportionate costs and burdens.  Today, thanks to the work of your rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs, we have proposals to offer proposals that concretely simplify EMIR rules and increase their transparency without increasing the risk to financial stability.  The Law and Justice Delegation strongly supports the current proposal also on the issue that divides us the most, namely the compromise on the temporary exemption from the obligation to account for pension schemes, both for large and small ones. We believe that the current proposal will avoid operating costs for small financial counterparties, which is expected to be as high as €1.5 billion.  Congratulations, Rapporteur, we will adopt a good document.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the original EMIR entered into force in 2012 and it is rightly considered the gold standard worldwide, but since the entry into force of EMIR it has been possible to identify areas where further attention is needed, or indeed where there is a risk of duplicative requirements which can add costs for firms dealing in derivatives. In particular, it is right that we are streamlining the reporting requirements by moving toward single-sided reporting. It is also positive that there will be exemptions for intra-group transactions and the removal of the backloading obligation. Furthermore, it is made clear in the EP report that data quality is more important than quantity. We must also must bear in mind the practical aspects of implementation of EMIR. Through the EMIR REFIT, we have been able to identify areas which can be further streamlined in the regulation. For example, an exemption for certain small financial counterparties from the clearing obligation, and it will now be possible for the Commission to suspend the clearing obligation in cases of instability in the markets. Finally, I am glad that the rapporteur has included a proposal to bridge the limbo period for pension funds. We must ensure that the pension funds are able to continue to make use of the exemption in the period between August of this year and the entry into force of the EMIR REFIT Regulation. This will be one of the key priorities for my Group as we move towards our negotiations with the Council. My thanks to the rapporteur and to the shadows.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. –Mr President, after the financial crisis, when the European Market Infrastructure Regulation (EMIR) was put in place, it resulted – and we welcomed that – not only in more transparency on the derivatives market, but also in more central clearing, which is a welcome development. There is still progress to be made, and the first positive aspect of the text that we are going to adopt is that we insist that central clearing should go up; the share of the market that should be centrally cleared cannot go down, it has to go up. Second, this idea of having more conservative methods to decide whether small financial counterparties are below the clearing threshold is also welcome. On these pension funds: I remember the study carried out by the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) showing how badly pension funds were funded. When pension funds have to resort not only to derivatives, but to over-the-counter derivatives to run their business, then something is probably badly wrong. They made promises that they cannot possibly hold. I do not think that this is a reason to exclude them from the obligation of central clearing. The two—plus—one is welcome, and they cannot complain about that; they have to run their businesses in a sustainable way. We are going to vote on this report, but I would finish by saying this: Warren Buffett mentioned these derivatives as weapons of mass financial destruction. This was not by chance. These products are used in such volumes that they dwarf the real economy. 30 or 40 years ago, we had a working economy and we did not have this mass of derivatives. There are probably a lot of these derivatives that are unneeded and dangerous, and this is still a work in progress. Secondly, central clearing houses are becoming ‘too big to fail’ institution. They are systemic, and we should better regulate on how we deal with them in case of crisis.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, as we all know – and indeed as the G20 leaders themselves acknowledged in Pittsburgh – derivatives were at the very heart of the global financial crisis. When we’re talking about the regulation of a market worth more than USD 500 trillion, we need to get it right. EMIR, the post-crisis framework for the regulation of over-the-counter derivatives, has its problems certainly, but it is a crucial instrument for ensuring financial stability. This review proposal bends over backwards in my view to meet the demands of the industry, an industry – let’s not forget – that just a decade ago brought our economies and societies to the brink of collapse. I share the concerns that this move reflects a more general effort by this House to roll back and unpick the financial regulations put in place after the crisis. The weakening of regulations may be targeted at the smaller market participants, but the nature of this market is that it is a chain of interdependencies that promotes risk volatility. We have a responsibility as legislators to ensure that the derivatives industry is bound by strict and high standard regulations on transparency, reporting and clearing, and this Parliament, I fear, is failing to meet that responsibility with the report in front of us.

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I suppose that it’s a positive thing in revising regulations on OTC derivatives – the trend is to make reporting requirements slightly less complicated and burden slightly fewer firms with them. Even these modest changes will, by the Commission’s own estimates, save billions of pounds every year. But how many more billions could be saved by scrapping the attempt to micromanage the markets completely? The volume of data collected is so vast that there is no way to analyse it in a timely fashion, if at all. And what will the regulators do once the data tells them that the OTC horse has bolted? Close the stable door? All that will be achieved is to discover that a white elephant preceded the horse. And if proof were needed that the EU has not learnt the lesson of the euro crisis and wants to let sleeping dogs lie, look no further than the Italian banks, dramatically increasing their use of securitisation – the same financial engineering as in the American sub-prime bubble. Who can forget that? Certainly not those who lost their homes. Italian banks have been falling over themselves to bundle up packages of their non-performing loans, wrap them up as CDOs, and sell them to other banks at a pace almost twice that seen last year. 25 billion – I repeat, 25 billion – has been sold like this in the first half of 2018, with some senior tranches guaranteed by – guess who? – the Italian Government. This is simply making the debt contagious all over again: a wolf in sheep’s clothing. All it does is create a new debt death-loop between Italian banks and their government. Italy’s debt still stands at 132% of GDP, and over 150% of GDP if you include TARGET2 liabilities. Unable to devalue its currency, public debt is like a snake eating its own tail. I can tell you: bolting horses, white elephants, sleeping dogs – a financial dog’s dinner, ladies and gentlemen, a financial dog’s dinner.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Talking to Mr Coburn is always a pleasure, because his plain language arrives but is far from content. EMIR's core objective is to strengthen the stability of financial markets in the EU through higher reporting and transparency requirements. The EU Commission's report concluded that high hurdles need to be removed, especially among non-financial counterparties. The reform proposals aim to improve the efficiency of the use of the funds. Many industrial and financial companies are directly affected by EMIR. The protection of business risks through reporting obligations entails costs. Yes, but it is right to reduce them where financial stability is not weakened, in order to prevent disproportionate lyant overheads, such as a double majority. It should remain with the financial company. We supported by a large majority the excellent report by my colleague Werner Langen. I am extremely grateful to him for debating today, dear Werner, before such negotiations are held in the trialogue. I call this an absolute possibility of democratic participation. It proposes to support the significant improvements in reporting requirements – in risk provisioning, in cutting red tape. It also tackles the aspect of the hitherto unregulated risk assessment of pension funds – its keyword was 'round table', really as a great opportunity for joint results. We stand by these steps of a modern set of rules for greater stability in the financial markets. Dear Mr Werner, thank you very much – a report that has a huge opportunity to gain broad majority support.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I support the EMIR REFIT proposal, namely the revision of the European market infrastructure regulation under the programme for sharp and efficient regulation, which revises the original EMIR regulation of 2012 by simplifying certain rules for financial and non-financial counterparties in the derivatives market, making it more proportional and , I quote, simpler, lighter, more efficient and less expensive. While stressing that the EMIR REFIT proposal makes several improvements, including the suspension of compensation and the calculation of the compensation threshold as well as the treatment of pension plans, I believe that pension plans should be encouraged to implement centralised solutions and compensations in a timely manner. Finally, I would like to welcome, in particular, the objective of the proposal to preserve financial stability and to expand central compensation.

name: Caroline NAGTEGAAL
text: Mr President, a good, fair and reliable pension provision is one of the pillars of our modern welfare state. This goes beyond just a government that provides a benefit after retirement age. This also means that citizens themselves put in money for a good income in their old age. The responsibility of the government is to ensure a good system in which as much money as possible earmarked for the pension actually ends up there. Leaving unnecessary money on the administrative bow without ensuring an efficient solution is precisely not how it should be done. I therefore sincerely regret that the rapporteur, together with the negotiating team, has chosen to give the pension funds and clearing houses only two years to find a solution to the clearing obligation. In order to do it right, more time is needed. Not taking that time will, unfortunately, lead to a proper, sound and fair pension provision being compromised. I am therefore pleased that this is only a parliamentary position: not the end point, but an intermediate step in Parliament's final agreement with the Council. I really hope and expect that in the trialogue negotiations on this legislation, the failure of this Parliament will eventually be repaired. Thank you very much.

text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I have no objections to the report, to the work done by colleague Lange, but I will draw attention to two elements that concern me. text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would also like to thank all the speakers for their positive contributions. name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Marian-Jean Marinescu, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common rules in the field of civil aviation and the establishment of the European Union Aviation Safety Agency, as well as on the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 216/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council (COM(2015)0613 - C8-0389/2015 - 2015/0277(COD)) (A8-0364/2018).

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking today about an extremely important regulation for the aviation industry, a regulation that sets out all the certification rules for all categories in its scope. I believe that the outcome of the negotiations is balanced, it takes into account both passengers and all the components of the industry: carriers, manufacturers, workers, personnel, traffic management, administration. Rules are proposed to ensure air safety, but also to ensure the necessary flexibility in the production of aircraft and equipment, necessary in the context of the rapid progress of technologies. The Regulation covers for the first time all components of the industry, thereby simplifying the work of the administration and beneficiaries. The competences of the ESAA and the powers of the national authorities are made very clear. The development of certification specifications is based on the principle of risk assessment. DG MOVE is obliged to update all secondary legislation, thanks to this principle, within a period of five years. This principle will, for example, allow the rules to be adapted to different categories of aeroplanes according to complexity and utility and will allow the cross-border flight of small aeroplanes. Rules on security and, in particular, cybersecurity are introduced for the first time. A European warning mechanism for overflying conflict zones is also included. The freedom of decision of beneficiaries concerning the certification authority and, at the same time, the possibility of the transfer of responsibility shall be ensured if the activity of an authority endangers the safety of passengers. The Commission has a rather important future responsibility in the development of secondary legislation, which covers issues extremely important for passenger safety and industry development, rapid access to flight data for distressed flights, ensuring traffic control in the event of unforeseen disruptions, integration of unmanned aircraft into air traffic. This last point is extremely important. The drone industry is growing a lot lately. Rules are needed to ensure not only flight safety, but also privacy and security. It is obvious that, in the coming period, the large number of drones and the number of applications for these drones will create quite a lot of problems from this point of view, and there is a need for some very clear rules in this direction.  Parliament is still looking forward to this secondary legislation. I want to thank the shadow rapporteurs, the rapporteurs of the political groups, because we worked very well together. I also thank the Commissioner for her support and thank the Estonian Presidency for the great effort she has made to reach this agreement.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for all the work that you have put into this file and for the continued support of Parliament, especially Mr Marinescu and his colleagues from the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN), for the Commission’s proposal. Parliament has played a major role in these negotiations. Now it is for plenary to confirm the compromise text that has been reached with Council last December. This will contribute to our common strategic objective of achieving a deeper and fairer internal market while fostering innovation, with a strong positive impact on jobs and growth. A safe and competitive European aviation industry needs an effective and balanced legislation such as the one which you will vote on tomorrow. This new regulation is also a centrepiece of the Commission’s 2015 aviation strategy for Europe, ensuring safe, secure and environmentally-friendly aviation for EU citizens. It does so through a better use of resources, the enforcement of risk- and performance-based requirements, and by eliminating unnecessary administrative burdens. In practical terms, we are changing the certification process to be more tuned in for innovation, which means shortening time-to-market and keeping our industry more competitive. This regulation closes the existing gap in the regulatory system and introduces effective, cooperative safety management processes. Importantly, it includes a system of pooling and sharing of resources between the Member States and EASA and establishes better governance for our aviation agency. Allow me to underline other key benefits of the new regulation. It takes into account new technologies and market developments to ensure that they are efficiently integrated into the aviation system as well as subject to effective and proportionate oversights. This is in particular the case for the safe operation of drones, with new provisions regarding registration of drones and drones’ operations. I wish to thank again Parliament, and particularly Mr Marinescu, for the strong support on this important topic. It is worth pointing out that we are going to get, for the first time EU-wide, a regulatory framework for drones. This regulation also takes into account the interdependencies between aviation safety and aviation security. In the future, EASA will play a role in aviation security, including cybersecurity, and contribute upon request with its expertise to the implementation of rules in this area. Another very important point for Parliament was the establishment of an oversight support mechanism. This objective has been achieved. This new mechanism will represent an important instrument for a high and uniform aviation safety in Europe. Let me finally mention that the Commission has prepared a declaration concerning the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS), as previously announced during the negotiations. The declaration should be attached to the plenary minutes and transmitted to the Council. With your positive vote tomorrow, the new EASA Regulation could enter into force in the second half of this year. The Commission is ready for this and has already started to prepare the implementation of this new regulation. Commission Statement (in writing) In the view of the Commission, services consisting of the emission of signals by satellites of core constellations of global navigation satellite systems (GNSS), such as the system established under the Galileo programme and other similar systems, are as such not to be considered as air traffic management and air navigation services (ATM/ANS) as defined in Article 3, read in conjunction with the corresponding recital, of new Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common rules in the field of civil aviation and establishing a European Union Aviation Safety Agency and repealing Regulation (EC) No 216/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council. This view is based, in particular, on the fact that those signals are not primarily or exclusively emitted for the purpose of air navigation, but are used for that purpose only through services that augment those signals, which are expressly covered by the definition of ATM/ANS.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the Commissioner for the introductory remarks. But I think a special word of thanks today suits my party colleague Marian Marinescu. This was a very tough dossier and he has brought several difficult discussions to a successful conclusion with the shadow rapporteurs. Aviation safety is one of the most important issues that the European Parliament can address here today. On 17 May, I myself, together with Mr Marinescu and other MEPs, visited EASA in Cologne. I am impressed by the agency's current approach and even more so of the tasks it will be given in the future. EASA also has a very good name internationally. After all, it is not just about the EU, but also about relations with the US, China and South America on aviation safety. I think that we in the European Parliament should be proud to have such an agency. Now there will be a task extension. It will no longer only be about aircraft and certification, but also about drones and soon also about the equipment at airports. These are all subjects that complete aviation safety. Interesting, of course, is the question: "Will the UK stay or not?". Of course, the UK cannot continue with aviation safety alone. So we will have to see how things develop. Thank you very much.

name: Gabriele PREUSS
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which As Members of this House, they all probably fly much more frequently than the average EU citizen. But have you ever thought about how fit and healthy or rested the pilot and crew are? How many flying hours can the pilot have or whether he still has to pay for his training, whether he is tired or sick? The fact that we get on a plane more relaxed than ever has to do with the fact that it has never been as safe to fly as it is today. And nowhere is it safer than here in the EU. Therefore, it is worth looking behind the scenes from time to time and making it clear again and again that the level of security and service we enjoy is not a matter of course. In the aviation sector, with some delay, something that we know from other transport sectors, such as shipping and road transport, is increasingly gaining ground: profit-making at the expense of workers. In the long term, this always leads to poorer services and, we are convinced, this is not good for security. Because safety is a difficult and detailed work, not only in the technical field. Those who work in the field of aviation safety must be able to carry out their tasks free of entrepreneurial pressure, must be optimally trained and trained and, of course, receive all the important information. In order to counter the worrying trend of social dumping, we have enforced Article 76a of the new EASA Regulation. EASA will now have the opportunity to look at windy business structures in which no one can understand who is actually responsible from the point of view of clear accountability. The same applies to employment models, in which pilots are almost urged to fly permanently and to reduce costs on the devil's point. These were truly memorable negotiations that we have had, and I would therefore like to thank Mr Marinescu, as rapporteur, and the Commission most sincerely for putting such a balanced report to the vote.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Ladies and gentlemen, we are taking a decision here not only for the designers, producers and operators of aircraft, but for all European citizens. The summer holidays are just about. Many holidaymakers will soon be getting back on a plane to their favourite travel destination and they want to do so in a safe and comfortable way. Perhaps this summer others will purchase their first drone or a European entrepreneur will provide the next innovation in the sector. More and more people are getting involved in aviation and the figures show that as well. By 2035, 14.4 million passenger flights will be operated in Europe. That is 50% more than in 2012. We are also seeing this steep flight in the drone sector, which will create 100 000 jobs over the next 20 years. A good thing for the economy, employment and competitiveness of the European Union. But let us not lose sight of the safety of passengers and the impact on people and the environment. Today we are taking an important step in the right direction. We embrace promising innovations, but also provide the necessary security framework. Proportionality, less red tape and a sense of reality are central to this. In this way, we facilitate innovative ideas and save recreational aviation a lot of headaches. In addition, we also provide specific rules for drones. An essential step to integrate these unmanned aircraft safely into our airspace. As with other devices, manufacturers and operators will have to pay attention to the security, privacy and protection of personal data in the future. A measure that benefits both users of drones and the people on the ground. Finally, I would ask the European Aviation Safety Agency to continue its proper functioning and to carry out its new tasks on a dutiful manner.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Europe is reaching yet another milestone to make flying even safer: with new European rules on the use and registration of drones, with new opportunities to use the specific knowledge of aviation inspectors across Europe, and with new tasks for the Aviation Safety Agency (EASA), to intervene when aviation safety is at stake. But new rules, new opportunities and new tasks call for cooperation between EASA and various authorities in the European Member States. For example, I am pleased that there will be a European system to warn European airlines about dangerous flight paths. Disasters such as those with flight MH17 may thus be prevented in the future. But that requires good cooperation between national intelligence services, aviation authorities, the European Commission and EASA. Intelligence agencies will collect and share information about risks when flying over conflict zones. Joint risk assessments are drawn up so that EASA can warn the European aviation sector of danger in a timely manner. Mr President, this calls for mutual trust and cooperation. This requires that paper rules be converted into workable solutions. I therefore call on the Member States to work together together and vigorously with EASA and the European Commission. Tomorrow we will put the new EASA regulation to the vote, but safety is calling for action today and every day. Because passenger safety should not be sold. Never.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, thank you Commissioner and thank you to our rapporteur, Mr Marinescu. Sometimes it is not easy to find agreements, but we have done it. I must tell you that we have one of the most efficient airspaces in the world in terms of safety in Europe and it is thanks to EASA, it is thanks to the European harmonisation of civil aviation standards that we now have this unique European sky.  But aviation is a sector that is changing and needs to adapt. On the one hand, technological changes, with the mass arrival of drones. It is true that we, the Greens, had asked for a check of drones from 250 grams, a European registration and a driver's license for all users. We've had less, but the most dangerous categories of drones seem at least well framed.  We will still remain very vigilant about future delegated actions and feedback from THE U-space programme led by SESAR, to fully understand how drone air traffic can be managed in a way that is 100% safe and unsafe. On the other hand, the air force is undergoing social changes. This sector is highly exposed to precarious jobs in models such as low-cost or some regular companies. We have long denounced certain practices allowed in Europe, such as zero-hours contracts, pay-to-fly contracts or false independent status. Finally, the legislation makes the link between security and social conditions of air workers so that never again a tragedy like that of the Germanwings can never happen. Finally, we are also experiencing an acceleration in traffic: by 50% by 2030, x 3 by 2050, forecasts show an acceleration of the sector completely incompatible with climate agreements and this is where EASA has an added value, since it has environmental skills, for progress to be made in the lightening of materials, the use of hydrocarbons and the electrification of soils. That is why we will vote tomorrow in favour of your report, Mr Marinescu.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr Chairman, dear colleagues, my greatest thanks to my dear colleague, Marian-Jean Marinescu. name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, thousands of flights take place every day in the skies of the Member States of the Union with millions of passengers. The importance of these flights, whether passenger or commercial, for the economies of the countries is enormous and of course irreplaceable. But we must ensure that all these routes are made with the maximum possible level of safety for both passengers and aircraft crews. I must stress that I am clearly in favour of the coordination of the various civil aviation services of the States, as such coordination can save lives. I therefore welcome the establishment of a pan-European agency to coordinate their respective national ones. However, it should have a purely coordinating role and under no circumstances should it be responsible for the control of air spaces itself, as they form part of the territory of each Member State and the granting of control constitutes a clear concession of national sovereignty. Especially in cases such as Greece, where Turkey is questioning the sovereignty of my country, granting control would mathematically lead to the loss of national territory. Finally, on drones: although it is a fact that a regulatory framework needs to be created, the proposed framework is out of reality, because drones are not only toys and tools, but also war machines.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Over the next 20 years, air traffic is forecast to increase by 50 percent from today's level. name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, finally, after two years of negotiations, we have the opportunity to vote on this important regulation. Aviation safety is vital. name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. If we vote on it tomorrow – and we should all be in favour of it – then we will have a good new regime for safety in Europe's airspace. EASA has done a very good job before and has now really been given an updated task, which is also partially extended. I would just like to mention five points. One is – this is only a small thing, but it was important to me – that one has exceptions in the annex: for single-seaters up to 300 kilograms, for two-seaters up to 450 kilograms, so that the bureaucratic burden is also partly lower. Above all, however, it is important that we have regulation for drones – that is crucial. There are more and more unmanned aerial vehicles that must be registered now. So this has to be exchanged nationally, it has to be available digitally – very, very important. We are trying to reduce the bureaucratic burden, that is a small thing. However, it is also very important that the military overflight zones are regulated. And it is very important to me as a German after the crash of the Germanwings plane: it cannot be that a pilot is tired of life and tears other people to their deaths. For this, too, we have now provided for things that can prevent something in this direction in the future. That is why I am looking forward to tomorrow's vote, which will be positive.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, the complexity and scope of the Regulation does not change, but the usual objectives continue: the establishment of a greater degree of harmonisation of the common rules of the field of aviation at EU level, the deepening of the single European sky, the worsening of the liberalisation of the transport and air navigation sector, with consequent concentration phenomena. A liberalisation which, in the name of financial profitability, has called into question labour rights, promoting the widespread precariousness of labour relations in the sector, but which has also opened the door to the degradation of the quality of services and even the levels of safety of operation and maintenance. This strategy includes the European Aviation Safety Agency, a symbol of the assault on the strategic sovereignty of peoples, with the transfer of powers from states to the European Union. What needs to be deepened and developed is cooperation between States through their national authorities, safeguarding the sovereignty of each country and respect for the rights of workers and service users.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Dear Commissioner, dear colleagues, I welcome the result of the trialogue with great pleasure also on behalf of my fellow pilots, who are pleased that the legislation – or, in order for the European Union to pay attention to their needs, has been on development. name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today's discussion is about legislation that is supposed to keep us safe in 15 years' time. name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: – Mr President, civil aviation operations by the Countries of the European Union and the USA currently account for more than 60% of the world's civil aviation. name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr President, we welcome the establishment of an Aviation Safety Agency of the European Union and support the package of measures to strengthen air transport safety. name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by My concern or concern is safety. The safety of not only those who fly, but also those who on the ground can be attacked by flying vehicles.  I would remind you that four years ago, in favour of creating a central passenger register, I was, with a certain group of course, in a minority. Terrorist attacks have changed these proportions. name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank honourable Members for this very positive and engaging debate. I have taken good note of your comments. I believe that we have a common understanding in considering this compromise as the right answer to the need to maintain a high level of civil aviation safety under the current challenges of growing traffic, while ensuring the competitiveness of European aviation. Before I conclude, allow me to make some comments on the topics that you raised. First, on social conditions, this topic has not been forgotten during negotiations. There are indeed new provisions in the regulation to make sure that interdependencies between social and safety aspects are adequately addressed by EASA. Let me also inform you that the Commission will continue to work on this during the year. In the second part of the year, we intend to issue reports on social issues in the aviation sector. On the question of oversight, let me say that the proposal includes a balanced and effective oversight support mechanism. This mechanism enhances the cooperative nature of the oversight system in Europe. It is driven by a clear timeline and planning of the activities and reserves the possibility to take further measures to ensure safety if necessary. I will make another comment on safety itself. Let me stress again that in Europe we have one of the highest – if not the highest – level of aviation safety, and it continues to improve year after year. This is clear evidence that the single European aviation market functions well and thus in no way compromises safety. On the contrary. I will make one quick comment on drones. EASA will ensure the safe coexistence of commercial aviation and drone activity for professional or recreational use. This implies, among others, an adequate design and use of our air space. The agency is already working on those issues, including in urban areas through the so—called urban aviation space or ‘U-Space’ as we normally call it. I have to say that this is a very important EU innovation. Before concluding, allow me to draw your attention to another crucial piece of legislation for the future of European aviation on which the European Parliament will be called upon to play a major role in the coming months, namely our proposal of safeguarding competition in air aviation, better known as the revision of Regulation 868. It is a priority to equip Europe with an efficient and credible instrument for the benefit of our industry, passengers and regions. Please bear in mind that the Council, under the Bulgarian Presidency, reached a general approach on this topic. I know that discussions with the Council will not be easy but, thanks to your support, I am confident that we will succeed.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the report by Mr Damiano Zoffoli, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on CO2 emissions and fuel consumption from new heavy vehicles (COM(2017)0279 - C8-0168/2017 - 2017/0111(COD)) (A8-0010/2018)

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this proposal for a regulation fills a serious gap: the lack, to date, of a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying data on carbon dioxide emissions and fuel consumption of heavy goods vehicles registered and placed on the European Union market. There is no common database containing all the monitoring data of the Member States. These data, at present, were neither certified, monitored nor communicated in an objective and comparable way, as is the case for cars and vans. This lack of information has led, first and foremost, to reduced competition between European heavy-duty vehicle manufacturers, with little incentive for innovation and the implementation of energy-efficient technologies. It has also made it impossible for transport operators, which are mainly small and medium-sized enterprises, over 500 000, to choose the most fuel-efficient vehicles and thus save on fuel costs, costs which account for a third of operating costs.  In addition, this lack of information has been a brake on action at national EU level to reduce emissions from heavy goods vehicles, bearing in mind that 25 % of co2 emissions from the road transport sector come from lorries, buses and coaches, which are responsible for 5 % of total emissions. However, a percentage that will increase, in the absence of intervention, to an estimated 10 %, thus doubling even to 2030.  Thanks to this regulation, data on carbon dioxide emissions and consumption of all categories of new production heavy goods vehicles will be available on the Website of the European Environment Agency over two years. The European Commission's proposal was already a good starting point and the work of discussion with our colleagues in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and with the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council and the Commission itself has enabled us to reach an even more ambitious compromise.  In particular, we have improved the quantity and quality of information that will be made public, increasing transparency, for example with regard to engine performance. The only exceptions will be cases justified by the need to protect sensitive private data and ensure fair competition between manufacturers. We then included with the mandatory checks, the provision for the relevant administrative sanctions, a provision that was absent from the Commission's proposal.  Another of the key points that we have insisted on as a Parliament is the inclusion of the result of roadside testing in the annual publication of data to compare vector data measured in the laboratory with emissions under real driving conditions. Mandatory co2 emission standards can now be set, which already exist for cars and vans, including for all heavy goods vehicles. I hope that this will take place in a not too long time, on the basis of the proposal for a regulation already dismissed by the Commission. Thanks to this regulation, we will have cleaner air in our cities and our mayors will have green buses available for school transport.  Europe is a movement. Europe is moving towards a more competitive and low-carbon economy than the current situation in which the transport sector is still 94 % dependent on oil. Today we are taking another step in the direction of a new alliance between industry and the environment, an alliance capable of creating new and good jobs. We are taking a step towards a more intelligent development model that is respectful of people's health and quality of life.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I am glad we are meeting today to finalise the adoption of the Regulation on monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions from heavy-duty vehicles. This is the first piece of legislation on CO2 emissions from lorries, buses and coaches. A swift agreement on this Regulation has been possible, thanks to the constructive efforts and spirit of compromise of the negotiators from both institutions. The agreement strikes a good balance between the need for transparency and the need to protect commercially-sensitive data, ensuring a robust and reliable monitoring and reporting system. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Zoffoli, and his team and congratulate them on the quick result. This regulation is a crucial instrument to close the current knowledge gap on the CO2 emissions and fuel consumption from heavy-duty vehicles put on the European Union market. The information made available with the publication of the reported data will be especially important for transport operators. In addition, the regulation paves the way for the CO2 emissions standards for lorries proposed by the Commission last month, which will need to rely on the data reported for its compliance processes. The support and steering of the rapporteur, Mr Zoffoli, as well as the active engagement of all shadow rapporteurs really paved the way to this good result. The European Parliament has strongly contributed to the final shape of the legal text. I would like to offer you two major examples: the introduction of administrative fines if manufacturers do not report the data or if the data reported deviates from their type-approval values, and the extension of the monitoring system to the results of future on-road verification tests. The Commission invites you to support this motion and continue the work with a swift negotiation of the CO2 emissions standards for lorries already on the table at both the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Many thanks to Mr Zoffoli and all the others who have helped to reach this conclusion! For our group, this was Christofer Fjellner, who is unfortunately apologetic today. Ladies and gentlemen, we now agree. That was not the case during the vote in committee and also at first reading in plenary. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats was dissatisfied because the rules did not take sufficient account of the protection of intellectual property. After the mandate of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Public Health ,the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and The Environment, Public Health and Social Affairs committee, we were concerned that the data would then come into the hands of other manufacturers and that these other producers outside Europe, for example in China, would benefit from it. That cannot be the point of European legislation that we support competition in China and elsewhere. Fortunately, this was then amended by the Council in the trialogue, and that is why we can vote in favour. The goal is important. In order to implement the Paris agreement on climate change, we must use all our potential. These are available not only for passenger cars and light commercial vehicles, but also for heavy-duty vehicles. For example, in the debate on legislation – specifically in the Dalli report and the other reports – we will see that the 40% target is already quite ambitious when it comes to implementation. That is why we need to think carefully and see how we get there. In all these questions, it is important for us not to reduce them in a general way, but also to see what is transported. Miriam Dalli has already presented her draft report for light commercial vehicles and passenger cars. A similar criterion is applied, irrespective of the size of a car and what is transported with it; the weight criterion shall be deleted without replacement. However, it cannot be the case that if you transport a family of six people, you have the same reduction targets as if you only drive a two-seater. We need to tighten up this once again, so that we can reach agreement on this procedure a little earlier and not only after the negotiations with the Council.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: for the S&D Group. Mr President! Thank you very much to Rapporteur Zoffoli for an excellent report and a very good result. So why is this a good result? Yes, I think most of us have tried to take a ride on motorways in the European Union, and there we see one lorry after another driving on the roads. There are simply so many trucks, and that is thus good for our trade, but it is not very good for the climate if our trucks and other heavy vehicles keep emitting as much CO2 as they do. About a quarter of all CO2 coming from the transport sector comes from trucks and other heavy vehicles. We need to get something done about that. The legislation on which we are about to vote is precisely a step in the right direction. This is the first legislation that will help us to monitor and report the CO2 emissions of lorries and other heavy-duty vehicles. This is absolutely essential if we are to be able to see what it looks like and to create a competitive situation in the EU's internal market. We need those who produce the trucks to make them more environmentally friendly, and one of the ways we can do that is to make sure that we know how much they emit and how much fuel they use. We in the Socialist Group do not believe that this is enough, but that we must move on. However, this legislation is, after all, a step in the right direction, so we warmly welcome the fact that we now have legislation that will enable us to do this. That is also the lesson of dieselgate: we know that more transparency is needed in this data. If we have that transparency in the data, then we also know that we can put pressure on for development so that we can have cleaner and better vehicles.  We are also very pleased that the European Commission has succeeded in providing tools so that they can issue fines if producers are not given the information they are required to provide. Again, because we know it's so important - this transparency in our data is a crucial tool to ensure that we have a more climate-friendly transport sector. Finally, it is also important to thank you for the fact that we will now also have the opportunity to carry out roadside tests. We know that it is not enough to test our heavy vehicles in the laboratories. They also need to be tested on the roads so we know if they are complying with the rules we are given. So thank you so much to Zoffoli for a very good result, and this is a step in the right direction to make the European Union more environmentally friendly and to meet the objectives of the Paris Agreement.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for At the outset, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his good and solid work. We know from the 2014 data that greenhouse gas emissions from heavy road vehicles are 5% of total greenhouse gas emissions in the European Union, as much as 20% of the greenhouse gas emissions of all transport (maritime, air and, of course, road) and 25%, or a quarter, of CO2 emissions from road transport. The ECR Group considers that an appropriate certification and monitoring system should be established and appropriately high standards for heavy road vehicles should be introduced. It is important for the Regulation to specify the various points that oblige manufacturers to monitor and consistently report certain information, so-called monitoring parameters (I would remind you that in more than 70 areas this data is not yet harmonised). We need to take into account very detailed technical parameters regarding gearbox, engine power or, finally, fuel consumption. Such a detailed approach is necessary for close cooperation with the various international organisations in order to contribute effectively to the monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions from heavy road vehicles and then to be able to draw appropriate conclusions and consequences. The ECR Group considers that the proposed regulation is very closely linked to the rules of transparency, but also to access to information. I would remind you that, in our opinion, the information should be public and, I do not hide, also public. We are very keen to maintain a compromise that would take into account well-known concerns about environmental protection on the one hand and intellectual property and international aspects of competitiveness on the other. Finally, the ECR considers that the proposed shape of the regulation is satisfactory.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Many thanks to the rapporteur, Mr Zoffoli, for his good work on this issue. There have been many oddities in European car policy. You don't measure the real exhaust or allow you to fiddle a little with the equipment. One of the oddities is the question we are now talking about: for lorries, heavy transport, there have been no rules at all.  When this discussion began, it was assumed that Parliament's call for a more environmentally friendly policy was really just a way of preventing the car industry's advance. In the meantime, the car industry has learned – it took quite an unnecessary amount of time – that by opposing the regulation of the various car sectors, it actually put itself in a very difficult situation, that is, it was technologically lagging behind and handed over a large part of the initiative to competitors.  Now we are at our best in the final phase of our work to achieve the practical rules for what this should look like for passenger cars. The next step in this direction, on the basis of the proposals we have received from the Commission, will be to take care of heavy transport as well. It will be particularly interesting because we know that the way in which we are going to share the burden between, for example, agriculture and heavy transport can present agriculture with serious challenges. Agricultural productivity is, of course, much lower if we do not take care of heavy transport taking its share of the Paris requirements, through COP21. In that case, we are putting agriculture at the same time in a worse situation. So we have taken a major step forward. We can take even greater steps in the future and that will also be necessary.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if you count on European roads, there are only 5% of trucks among all vehicles in circulation. Yet these trucks produce about 25%, or a quarter, of the greenhouse gas emissions from road transport in the European Union. It is high time that we put an end to this imbalance if we are to one day respect the commitments of COP 21 to save the climate and the planet, but also so that citizens can breathe. Putting in place monitoring OF CO2 emissions and truck fuel consumption is good news. Until recently, CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of HGVs were neither reported nor monitored objectively and comparablely in the European Union. From now on, transport operators will be able to choose the least consumer and emitting vehicles: this will allow them to spend less and pollute less. Let's not stop there, the road freight sector must do more and better to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions. The step we are taking today, of course, is necessary, but above all it must serve as a basis for the near future, that is to say to establish mandatory CO2 emission limits for all trucks in the European Union. The Commission has recently made proposals for a complete decarbonisation of the sector by 2050. I would hope that, again, we will be there, ladies and gentlemen, to give more strength, concrete and ambition to this proposal so that the road freight sector will emit 50% less greenhouse gases by 2030 and more by 2050. So if we stick to it, then we have a chance to respect our agreements, especially COP 21, because we all dance on the same volcano in the face of climate change, so let's seize this opportunity.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, special thanks to Mr Zoffol and to the entire negotiating team and, of course, also to the Team of the Commission and the Council for the common outcome. Reliable monitoring of fuel consumption and CO2 emissions from heavy-duty transport has been in the search before this bill. Now we have access to information on both fuel consumption and CO2 emissions. When this is combined with municipal type-approval and real emissions during driving, we can see that we have tools to combat climate change. I believe that funding is the key to the best ways in which we achieve our climate objectives. I would therefore like eu transport funding to be set as a criterion for assessing how projects contribute to achieving emission reduction targets, and funding to be targeted primarily at such projects where emission reductions are sufficiently high.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, until yesterday we had no data on emissions or even on fuel consumption. Today, finally, with this regulation, we are introducing monitoring and reporting of data on CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles. I welcome this and congratulate the rapporteur on leading Parliament in the negotiations.  This regulation fills a gap, because finally the comparison of the data obtained thanks to vector simulation software collected in the public register that is being set up will allow small and medium-sized enterprises and public administrations to make informed purchasing choices, orienting them – hopefully – towards models that generate the greatest fuel savings and not only , of course, we are also talking about emissions. Let us not forget, however, that the most important battle will be played out in the coming months, with the setting of CO2 reduction targets for these vehicles, which alone are responsible for 30 % of total road traffic emissions with worrying growth projections.
