name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, it is on the basis of the observation that 38% of greenhouse gas emissions come from road transport that the Commission presented in 2017 a system for monitoring and reporting data on CO2 emissions from new heavy-duty vehicles. In doing so, the Commission risks being inconsistent.  Indeed, in parallel with this desire to reduce CO2 emissions which led France to promote the diesel engine, which allows it to display CO2 emissions more than 10% lower than the European average, the Commission has embarked on the hunt for diesel in favour of petrol. However, it is clear that petrol engines, consuming more than diesel engines, ultimately emit 25% more CO2 than diesel engines. So it's a vicious circle and builders don't know what to expect. On the one hand, the hunt for CO2, on the other, the hunt for diesel. Once again, it will be a punitive ecology, with administrative fines that will go directly into Europe's pockets, which will hit the heavy goods industry at the expense of a policy encouraging good practices in eco-driving and supporting manufacturers and equipment manufacturers towards economically viable environmental objectives. The Commission's proposal is all the more unreasonable because it does not take into account the reality of the truck manufacturing and use process at all. Indeed, the manufacturers manufacture bare chassis which are then intended for different types of transport depending on the car under the trailer chosen for final use. The manufacturer's data thus becomes unusable and de facto useless factory data, but which will actually increase the bill of the finished product. So the only option that manufacturers currently have is to turn to alternative fuels that emit less CO2, such as LNG or electricity. This is already what many manufacturers are doing; but the technocrats behind this text simply forget that these different types of fuel, if adapted to certain short journeys, are - to date and for some time yet - relatively unusable on long-term journeys. In this context, it would be more in the Commission's interest to encourage the development of charging points and distribution of alternative fuels before coming to tackle manufacturers who are content to meet a demand of a specific type of vehicle and corresponding to the current needs and possibilities.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: Mr President, thank you very much. In the Netherlands we have the wonderful proverb: "without transport everything stands still". Road transport in the European Union is an economic factor of great importance. Our economy is still largely run on road transport. If you look at the discussions on the mobility package this week, you know that road transport is very important for the European economy. But we all signed COP21 in December 2015 and we also want the transport sector to be cleaner. That shouldn't take too long. In this respect, I agree with Mrs Bulc. At the same time, clean trucks also bring innovation. It is not so bad that politics is giving a nudge here and there to accelerate this innovation. In that respect, I would like to draw attention to the city. As I understand it, our buses are also covered by these heavy vehicles, and pollution from buses is a really big theme in different cities. Finally, Mr President, I am pleased that the trialogue has also been able to resolve the debate on data and industrial ownership. European industry, I think, was rightly concerned that excessive access to data could lead to industrial stealing. I understand that this has been brought to a successful conclusion in the trialogue.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In fact, here in the European Parliament, we are asking ourselves almost every day how we, as the European Union, are going to achieve the Paris climate targets. We know how important it will be to achieve the Paris targets and, unlike transatlantic partners, we are convinced that this agreement will ensure that we in Europe will contribute our fair share of the reduction of greenhouse gases. This also means, however, that we have to look at the greenhouse gas emissions emitted in the transport sector of lorries. We know that 5% of all greenhouse gas emissions in Europe come from the commercial vehicle sector, and that is why it cannot be explained to anyone – not to the citizens, but not to the companies that buy trucks – that CO2 emissions have not yet been monitored and have not yet been certified. It is therefore time, and it is right – and that is why I would also like to thank my colleague Mr Damiano for conducting these negotiations so well – that we finally have a proposal on the table that will ensure that we have transparency in this very important area. It is good that we have negotiated sanctions in this paper, so that we can also make manufacturers who do not comply with the transparency obligations responsible, sanction them, because we are all working every day to reduce CO2 emissions, and the manufacturers of heavy goods vehicles must do the same. It is also important that we give truck buyers the opportunity to base their purchasing decisions on how much CO2 a truck emits. We are still seeing an increase in lorry traffic within the European Union, while freight traffic by rail is decreasing, even though rail transport would be much more climate-friendly. In this respect, this proposal is also an approach to create more transparency and more market justice and to get more goods from road to rail. One final point: we all know that manufacturers of internal combustion engines tend to circumvent our requirements. That is why it is a great success, an important step, that we have introduced tests that measure real emissions. Overall, I believe that this package is a good and important step for citizens.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done on this report. First of all, thank you very much to the rapporteur: this has really become a good law. I could join me immediately, dear Tiemo Wölken, and say, I fully agree with you. That is not what this is about, however, and I am supposed to give my own speech. In fact, if it is only 5% of the CO2 emissions emitted by lorries and heavy goods vehicles, it is 25% of road transport and we urgently need to improve. We also need a lot of traffic, consumers want to buy products that need to be transported. But it really cannot be that we have not yet had standards. That is why it is unlikely that we actually have standards for these emissions and for measuring efficiency for the first time. It's crazy: the US, China - even China! – Japan, Canada, they all have that and we don't have it yet. We are now measuring this in real road traffic. It's also a very important story that we're doing this now, not somewhere in the lab. And we publish the data – it is especially important to me that we protect sensitive data and intellectual property. But overall we are in a very good direction for the carbonization of transport. What we have now is good for the environment, good for transparency and takes us forward.

name: Julia REID
text: – Mr President, this report states that global warming is a real problem requiring clear and courageous decision—making, and yet there has been no discernible increase in global temperature since the late 1990s, despite an increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide. It would appear that initial climate models have been too pessimistic, with empirical data temperatures diverging from those forecast 10 years ago and climate scientists now admitting that previous forecasting models had exaggerated the amount by which temperatures would rise.  What we are experiencing is a relatively inactive sun. Sunspot activity has been decreasing since 1996, with the sun being completely blank for 25% of last year, and to date, 2018 appears to be no different. In fact, solar scientists are predicting another Maunder Minimum. In my opinion, it would be best to adopt a wait and see attitude rather than to continue with current unilateral EU energy and climate policies that are profoundly damaging to the European economy, causing industry closures and job losses.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report There is, of course, no question at all: we need to act! Like probably everyone here, I am curious to see how the current events at Daimler will develop. If we add the truck cartel to Volkswagen's history, it must be said that the industry absolutely needs rules and controls. Stricter rules and reviews are needed, not only because of limited trust, but also so that we can review how our decisions work in practice. I very much doubt that taxes on fuels have saved even a spark of CO2. This will only make road transport more expensive for users and consumers. I believe wholeheartedly that the majority of this House and of Europe share the same objective. The environmental impact is to be reduced, the sector should contribute to climate protection, and we should get away from oil, also for geopolitical reasons. Synthetic fuels not only protect the environment, but also reduce our dependence and bring the value chain back to Europe. The batteries do not solve this problem, but actually create new ones. I would therefore like to warn against giving in in the light of current events and focusing exclusively on the road and the internal combustion engine. Obliging lorries to pay a certain levy per kilometre because of noise, pollutants and CO2 emissions does not help humans, animals or the environment. Only the Finance Minister is happy. Further development of engine and exhaust technology helps, as the Euro standards have impressively demonstrated. The costs cannot simply be passed on to the consumer, but are being pushed in the right direction by manufacturers. Once again, we need monitoring, but we certainly do not need the organic indulgence trade.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, global warming must be tackled with clear and courageous decisions. The European Union has set a binding and ambitious target of at least 40 % reduction in greenhouse gas emissions in all sectors of the economy by 2030 and it is clear that, in order to meet this target, the transport sector has a very important contribution, and in particular heavy transport, as a quarter of CO2 emissions are due to this type of road transport.  CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy goods vehicles placed in the European Union are not, as we all know, subject to certification, surveillance or data communication, as is already the case with passenger and commercial light vehicles.  And that is why this proposal for a regulation is welcome, because it fixes a gap. Only with robust and reliable data can good legislation be made. I have therefore been slammed for this, as shadow rapporteur, in the group that is currently working on the trilogues of the energy union governance regulation negotiations. An integrated approach from all sectors so that we can achieve the desired objectives. In this proposal, precise requirements are laid down for monitoring and reporting of emissions, which will allow the establishment of a database, something very positive, transparent, managed by the European Environment Agency and important will also be the annual report of the European Commission. This regulation is part of the European Low Carbon Mobility Strategy and is an important step towards the decarbonisation of transport, but we must not lose sight, as has already been said, that in the near future we must have clean and intelligent mobility models and that these clean and intelligent mobility models also have to be applied to heavy vehicles.  This is, moreover, another area in which, in the name of health, sustainability and the competitiveness of European industry, the European Union must resume a leading role on a global scale. Thank you very much.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are, of course, talking about a very important subject, because it involves the protection of climate and air, and this is extremely important nowadays. This has an impact on people's health, but when we talk about people, we must also remember those who work in factories where vehicles are produced and in companies using these vehicles. I would like to say that a certain balance must be struck between needs and opportunities.  It is also important that we increase the level of expected reductions in CO2 and all other components harmful to air and our health in proportion to technical progress. Because, of course, it's very easy to think that emissions should be cut by 15%, 30%, 50%, 70% by this year – so you can throw – but the question remains whether this is technically possible.  I would therefore call for the Commission, in parallel to such projects, to also provide for measures to support science, research and development towards the creation of new technical and technological solutions that will facilitate the achievement of these objectives.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I should like to begin by thanking my colleague Damiano Zoffoli, for the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and my colleague Nicola Caputo, for the Committee on Transport and Tourism, for their work on this important dossier. The transport sector contributes significantly to total emissions in the European Union and heavy goods vehicles play a predominant role. Europe's targets for reducing emissions are ambitious, and I believe that these will be difficult to achieve if we are not able to monitor and compare data on heavy goods vehicles, as we already do for cars and light vehicles.  If we want to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in road transport by 60 % by 2050, we must also have a system for monitoring emissions and consumption for heavy goods vehicles. Moreover, this is proposed by the European 2016 strategy for low-emission mobility. Finally, it will therefore be possible to have reliable data on both fuel consumption and emissions for these vehicles too. After the Dieselgate scandal, in fact, it is increasingly necessary to collect and disseminate data on real driving emissions, and not those calculated in the laboratory. The data collected will be managed in a database by the Environment Agency, but never before am I convinced that there is also a need for a road transport agency, which could not only ensure that this information is accessible to the public, but also that sensitive and commercial data is protected.  The most important thing, however, is the effect for the citizens, who want to be able to breathe cleaner air, with undoubted health benefits, but there will also be a positive effect for road hauliers, who will have savings on consumption.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I’m glad I made it, just in from Strasbourg, three and a half hours on the bus, so it’s good to make my speaking time. I am pleased to support this proposal, which looks to put in place an EU-wide system for monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions and fuel consumption for manufacturers’ heavy-duty vehicles, or HGVs. As part of this mandatory system, the findings would be cross-checked against new vehicle registration data as provided by Member States. At present, HGVs account for approximately a quarter of the EU’s CO2 emissions from road transport – a very high sum. It is anticipated that this will increase significantly, along with growing levels of road transport in the coming years, unfortunately. Thus it is imperative that we take action as soon as possible to ensure a sizeable reduction in new HGV CO2 emissions in the 2020-2030 period. The primary aspects of the proposal include introducing administrative fines where there is infringement in clearly-defined cases; making public certain data reported under the regulation, including air drag value in a range format; provisions to monitor and report results of on-road verification tests; measures to verify and correct other measures adopted by implementing acts. These are all important inclusions, and I think they will certainly help the situation. I am encouraged by this proposal and the opportunities it will create, as well as enabling fleet buyers to make more informed purchase decisions in order to boost competition between manufacturers and stimulate fuel efficiency and lower emissions in the freight sector. We depend heavily on innovation to sufficiently reduce our transport emissions, and I am certain there is a great potential to make significant strides forward in this regard. We will need to make real cuts in transport by 2030 if we are to comply with the commitments on the recently adopted effort-sharing regulation, and as rapporteur for the renewable energy file which we are completing, hopefully, this week, I think this is a positive step.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur, Mr Zoffoli, and also the Commission and the Bulgarian Presidency for their good cooperation here. I myself have been responsible for this issue in the EPP Group.  Without the truck, Europe will stop. We simply cannot do without it, and that is why we must do what we can to combat emissions from lorries. They account for a significant proportion of emissions. In Sweden alone, for example, road traffic accounts for about 30% of emissions and lorries account for 20% of that share.  There is a myth that trucks are not becoming more and more efficient. That is not true; they become more effective. In Sweden alone, emissions from heavy goods vehicles decreased by 11 per cent last year. It's not so strange; The person who buys a truck wants above all a truck that is fuel efficient, because that is the biggest cost when you buy a truck. Market forces work here very well to help the environment. The only problem is that it is not declining fast enough, and that is what we need to do something about. That is why we now have legislation to ensure that we better measure CO2 emissions from our heavy goods vehicles, and soon together we will also find legislation to limit emissions from heavy goods vehicles.  The big question we have debated here, and had conflicts about, is what information should become public. I have had an important principle that the information that manufacturers should have to publish about their products is the information we need to measure emissions, but some here seem to have the principle that all information on everything possible should be accessible to all. Almost as if the goal were for our products to be copied by others. Europe is a world leader in producing trucks and that is how it should remain, but then we will export environmentally friendly trucks, not sensitive information about how we produce our trucks. That is why I think that the trade-off we have struck here – to ensure that we publish information that reduces emissions, not that allows others to copy our trucks – is what is important. Because if we do that, then we export sensitive information, we export jobs and growth from Europe.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this debate which confirms the importance to act on CO2 emissions from heavy-duty vehicles. Together we can be proud of the result of our joint effort to agree on this new piece of legislation. But before I conclude, allow me to respond to some of your comments. On transparency of data: the agreed text strikes the right balance between the need for increased transparency in the heavy-duty vehicle market and the need to protect commercially sensitive information. This approached, agreed for the publication, does strike such a balance considering the high influence of this parameter to the fuel consumption performance and hence CO2 emissions of vehicles. Of course I am referring to the air-drag values. On in-service conformity tests, this provision has the objective of ensuring that consumers get what they pay for and that the cars that are produced are as clean as the ones that are tested. The Commission had already included this provision in the context of the type approval reform, and the European Parliament had strongly backed this position during trilogues. Unfortunately, the final compromise for type approval did not manage to keep this provision. This is why we included it again in this legislation. Hopefully this time we will succeed. On alternative fuels, the Commission issued, in its second mobility package last November, a detailed action plan to accelerate the deployment of alternative fuels infrastructure throughout the EU. This also includes fast charging points for electrical vehicles, and the Commission dedicated EUR 450 million of cofinancing in its November 2017 CEF call to support these efforts. So the projects are now in the deployment phase. On diesel cars the Commission sees a need for accelerating the uptake of zero and low-emission vehicles in an effort to improve air quality and lower CO2 emissions, while following an approach of technological neutrality. While the proposal will speed up the market uptake of zero and low-emission vehicles, accelerating innovation and reaching economies of scale, the change in the fleet composition will be gradual. It is expected that at least 80% of new car fleets in 2030 will contain an internal combustion engine. So I do hope that additional innovation will be introduced, for use in combustion engines to qualify for at least low-emission vehicles. On imported vehicles: there is no doubt that all vehicles placed on the European market are subject to the same standards, either being manufactured here in Europe or imported from third countries. Finally, let me again stress the benefits of addressing HDV emissions, very quickly. First, transport operators, mainly SMEs, will save money at the pump. Second, we will keep and create new jobs here in Europe, up to 25 000 more jobs in 2025 are estimated. Third, we will invest and innovate here in Europe. Fourth, we will use and import less oil. And fifth, we will fight against climate change and improve the air we breathe, in particular in EU cities. So, as a next step, the Commission counts on the co-legislators to replicate the success of this file when negotiating the CO2 emissions standards for lorries.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. – Transport is responsible for a quarter of EU GHG emissions. Since 2013, despite warnings from the scientific community, emissions from this sector have continued to grow, threatening to meet the objectives of the Paris Climate Agreement. As they are not subject to emissions trading, it is states that have to develop transport policies for emission reduction, but little or nothing can be done with economies heavily conditioned by the automotive industry, on which up to 10% of GDP depends. Thus, the sector continues to produce polluting vehicles, with a more than amortized model, and there is no change even in the face of high real demand for electric vehicles, to such an extent that German delivery companies have had to manufacture their own vans. Without penalties in Europe for distorting emissions and with governments and Commission frightened by job loss or relocation, even the fulfilment of the less ambitious objectives is moving away. The new measures taken for combustion engine emissions will be of no use without a real commitment to the electrification of the transport of goods in all their senses.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. – The low-carbon circular economy is a major OBJECTIVE of the EU. Achieving this objective is supported by an investment plan aimed at reindustrialising Europe on the basis of new business models and cutting-edge technologies. As is well known, in order to transition to clean energy for all Europeans, the EU has set ambitious emission reduction targets by 2030, to which the transport sector must also contribute. However, so far, CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy vehicles placed on the EU market have not been certified or monitored and reported, which creates a barrier to the establishment of policies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the heavy vehicle sector. Therefore, the monitoring and reporting system for new heavy vehicles proposed at Union level will contribute to the creation of a fully transparent market for new heavy vehicles, which will enable buyers to make the best informed purchasing decisions, giving manufacturers a stronger incentive to innovate and develop more energy efficient vehicles.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the report by Krystyna Łybacka, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the modernisation of education in the EU (2017/2224(INI)) (A8-0173/2018).

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by First of all, I would like to thank all those involved in this report very warmly. I thank the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation, I thank the Committee on Employment and the Committee on Women's Rights for their valuable opinions, I thank the Commissioner for his active cooperation and the Commission for the numerous communications. I would like to express my special thanks to the experts in the field of education, teachers, students, pupils and NGOs for their invaluable remarks. When I worked on the report, I adopted three main assumptions. Firstly, the traditional place of learning, the school, is today replaced by many other available sources. Modern technologies have freed up education, creating an educational space. A huge challenge for us is to create a school as the most interesting place of this space. Secondly, we appreciate the role of vocational education, we stress in the report the need to create a set of key competences, skills, but we remind you that the role of education systems is to educate a multidimensional man who is not only professionally, but also culturally, socially and civicly. Thirdly, we believe that the establishment of a civilisation pact based on well-funded high-quality education systems is a prerequisite for all development. That is why we are calling for both increased investment and greater synergies between the Structural Funds, investment funds and education. The report considers all levels of education. We stress the importance of pre-school and early childhood education. We support the establishment of a European framework for pre-school education in order to ensure the holistic development of the child. We see schools as centers of critical and creative thinking. This, of course, requires a paradigm shift in education, a shift away from verbal communication and mechanical memorization in favour of understanding, discussion, problem solving, but also the individualisation of the learning process.  Higher education plays a key role in the development of the intellectual potential and competitiveness of the European economy. We are very interested in the announcement of the creation of a European education area, but we stress that it must be correlated with the European Higher Education Area and the European Research Area in order to strengthen the knowledge triangle and achieve pro-innovation attitudes among graduates. We also support the creation of a European network of universities, assuming, however, that this should be a bottom-up initiative of the universities themselves.  There will be no change in education without teachers, so we draw attention to the need to recruit highly motivated, well-educated and mentally prepared teachers. However, this requires both a change in the way they are educated and a great deal of concern to improve their professional and material status. We have received with great interest the announcement of the creation of a European Teacher Academy, especially after the evident success of the January Education Summit. Let us remember the words of the British educator John Dewey: "If we teach as we taught yesterday, we take our children tomorrow."

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by First of all, I would like to congratulate Krystyna Łybacka on an excellent report. I am responsible for preparing the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and in this opinion we emphasise that quality education is the right of every European and that the objectives of education go far beyond preparing graduates to find themselves on the labour market, although this labour market objective is of course very important.  We also note that the digitisation and automation of the labour market are changing the type of skills needed in the market. The demand for advanced skills and professions, including digital, mathematical, engineering skills, is increasing and the need for simple, non-skilled work is reduced. This fact should finally be taken into account by Member States in their education policies, which must effectively combat secondary illiteracy and school drop-out, as well as better educate university students.  We also stress that there is a growing demand for soft skills in the labour market that require practical, open, environmental education, and that teachers, the quality of their education and the freedom to choose a curriculum and teaching methods are key to a good quality education.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, Madam Łybacka, I’m very pleased to have this debate with you today. You underline in your report the crucial role of education in shaping the future of Europe. I couldn’t agree more. The transformation of our societies and economies creates changing education realities that need urgent responses if we want to offer bright futures to all our young people. In fact, over the last year or so the topic of education has visibly moved up on the EU’s agenda. In March 2017, the Rome Declaration called for a Union where young people receive the best education and training and can study and find jobs across the continent. In November last year, EU leaders debated education at the Gothenburg Social Summit and adopted conclusions on the topic at the December European Council.  With this mandate, the Commission has recently outlined its vision for a European education area where people can move freely to study, learn and train, and where we can offer high quality and innovative education for all our citizens. I thank you for your explicit support for the European education area. This project is based on three objectives. Firstly, to promote cross-border mobility and cooperation in education and training. Secondly, to remove unjustified obstacles that make it difficult to learn, train or work abroad. Our aim is to make the free movement of learners possible and to create a genuine European learning space. Thirdly, to support Member States in making their education and training systems more inclusive and innovative and to base them on the idea of lifelong learning. On 22 May 2018, we proposed a second set of concrete steps towards turning the vision of a European education area into reality following a first batch of proposals we tabled in January. In May, the Commission presented three proposals for Council recommendations. First, a recommendation on the automatic mutual recognition of higher education and upper secondary education diplomas and the outcomes of learning periods abroad. I firmly believe that we can only succeed in building a strong European identity if young people are free to study and learn in another EU country, unimpeded by administrative hurdles. Let us remove the recognition obstacle, at least inside the EU, once and for all.  Second, we want a comprehensive approach to the teaching and learning of languages. Our societies, our economy and the European project itself depend on our citizens being able to communicate with each other. Alas, multilingualism is far from being a reality in the EU. It is high time we stepped up our efforts to be a truly multilingual Europe. Third, high-quality early childhood education and care systems. Evidence shows that if learning opportunities are missed at an early age, it takes much greater efforts to make up the deficit later. The Commission proposal aims to create a quality framework for early childhood education and care with the aim of giving all children the best possible start in life. We have outlined some key initiatives in support of the European education area. Let me mention just some them. First, the European universities. These will boost cross-border cooperation between higher education institutions. Higher education institutions which share the same vision and values will develop long-term institutional strategies for top quality education, research and innovation. The Commission aims to launch pilot projects in 2019 and 2020 under the Erasmus+ programme. Second, the European student card will simplify learning mobility by reducing administrative burdens and costs for students and educational institutions. The aim is to make it available to all Erasmus students by 2021 as a visible symbol of European student identity.  Third, with the graduate tracking initiative, we have launched the first ever European survey of graduates in eight pilot countries, with initial results expected by the end of 2019. All these initiatives build on the first proposals on the European education area we put forward in January. Back then, the Commission had launched an ambitious digital education action plan. This promotes digitalisation and innovation-driven approaches in education. A new European framework of key competences reminds us that we have to invest more in developing basic and digital skills, civic competencies and entrepreneurial attitudes, and we have to encourage more young people to study science, technology, engineering and mathematics. Finally, the Council recommendation on promoting common values, inclusive education and the European dimension of teaching was also tabled in January and adopted by ministers in May. Never before has the EU said so clearly how important it is to promote our common values, to create a sense of belonging, to teach about the functioning values and origins of the European Union and, most importantly, to learn about the cultural and historical diversity of Member States.  Madam Łybacka your excellent report and its constructive recommendations come at just the right moment. On 30 May, we presented our proposals for the future Erasmus programme, which will continue to play a key role in delivering the objectives of the European education area.  Let me take this opportunity to warmly thank this House for your unwavering support for an ambitious Erasmus programme post 2020, with an increased budget that is proportionate to the size of our ambition. I agree that we need to make the programme more inclusive and accessible. Our proposal will allow 12 million people, more than ever before, to participate in different types of exchanges while reaching out to more people of all social backgrounds. In order to reach new groups of learners, the Commission proposes to increase support for school pupil mobility, mobility of learners in vocational education and training, and youth mobility.  Furthermore, the Commission wants to provide more flexible formats for learning mobility, such as short-term and group activities and virtual mobility. We also want to make it easier for smaller and grassroots organisations to take part, in particular community-based organisations that work with disadvantaged learners of all ages.  I would like to thank you, Madam Łybacka, for your excellent cooperation in drawing up this report. All of you are a key partner for us in supporting Member States in improving and modernising Europe’s education systems.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – Mr President, European education must, above all, strive to develop thinking and thinking. This sentence from my colleague Łybacká's report should be carved in stone. I agree with many of the proposals in the report, but like the drafter of the opinion in the FEMM Committee, Mrs Shoydrová, I did not share some of them. I support the emphasis on teachers and their rewards, including the issue of the feminisation of education, the issue of equal opportunities for boys and girls and girls' motivation for some disciplines. The report also emphasises much-needed media literacy, which is the best long-term means of combating fake news and disinformation and making children safer online. In this report, therefore, we rightly call on the Commission and the Member States to develop special measures to support media and digital literacy projects.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Firstly, I would like to thank Krystyna Łybacka for her excellent cooperation in preparing this report, a very good and meaningful report has been prepared, congratulations on the work done. The report emphasises the importance of education, its economic and social aspects in the changed information society. Youth unemployment remains worrying in many Member States, but knowledge and qualifications are still the highest, with a lower unemployment rate among graduates than among those without qualifications. It is therefore important that Member States invest in improving the quality of education systems and infrastructure in response to current challenges, updating curricula so that students can acquire useful, applicable and practical knowledge. The report emphasises the importance of vocational training and dual training, the coordination of educational institutions and content with the world of work, labour market and contemporary needs, and the increase in the prestige of vocational work. I am pleased that the subject of the mother tongue education of national minorities has also been included in the report, since the right to use the mother tongue is an existential issue for minorities in the process of education. The report states that Member States should make greater efforts to ensure that pupils from indigenous minorities have access to all levels of education in their mother tongue and that institutions teaching minority languages receive priority support. The recommendations included the acquisition of a full range of key competences, such as foreign languages, digital skills and entrepreneurship, not least the competence of lifelong learning. The report pays particular attention to teachers: Member States should encourage young people to choose the pedagogical profession in order to make the teaching profession attractive and prestigious again, and teacher training has a key role to play. Following the good example in Hungary, it was included in the report's recommendations that Member States should make greater efforts to access early and early childhood education, so that Member States can provide more places for kindergartens and crèches, especially for children from disadvantaged families. Since 2010, the Hungarian Government has launched a number of initiatives in the field of early childhood education and public education, providing free school meals and textbooks for students. This is a good example of the early catch-up that many states need. I hope that this House will vote in favour of this report by a large majority.

text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Dear Mr. Vracics, I supported Kristina Lybatzka's report because I believe that modernising education is something we cannot continue to delay. We live in a time when new technologies and digitalisation are evolving at a rapid pace and education systems need to keep up with these developments. Otherwise, our educational establishments will continue to produce future unemployed and staff who do not master the skills of the 21st century. When talking about modernizing education, this should not be understood as renovating only the material base of educational establishments and buying modern equipment. It is important to keep up with new technologies, but they do not guarantee adolescents that they will be able to better learn, skills and competences. name: Jill EVANS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and express our support for this report. Quality education creates active and engaged citizens and increases the employability and mobility of young people, as well as contributing to building the economy as a whole. The modernisation of education systems across Europe is a pressing need, and one that must address deep structural challenges. It is the responsibility of Member States and devolved governments – such as we have in Wales, where full powers over education are devolved – to implement reforms, but the EU can assist their efforts. This report presents excellent recommendations on how to do that. One point that I especially welcome, and one that has been mentioned by several colleagues, is the importance given to the teacher as a guarantor of quality teaching. Earlier this year, I went with some others here on a study visit to Finland. Teachers there are highly trained and highly respected. To become a teacher, candidates must have passed at least a master’s degree, and many students try to be accepted on training courses for teachers and fail. It was clear that the status of teachers within society also changed the view of the value of education itself. So I am very glad that this report calls for measures to raise the status of the teacher. With the creation of the European Education Area under way, this is a crucial period where cooperation across the EU must be a priority. I hope that Wales, the country that I represent, will play its full part in these developments, and I will work towards that aim.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, today in the field of education, as a result of the anti-popular and anti-social policies implemented and implemented in the European Union and in the Member States, we note the following: general degradation of education policies and underfunding of public education, shrinking the labour rights of teachers and teachers, increasing the proportion of socially excluded citizens and increasing the brain drain phenomenon from Greece and other southern countries, promoting individualism at the expense of collective awareness, education systems with the overriding aim of serving the needs of the labour market, participants full of anxiety and anxiety due to the very difficult situation they will face after study. These policies in the context of neoliberal and austerity policies are aimed at creating even greater inequalities and concentrating wealth even more in the hands of a few. Modernising education, in order to be in the interests of the many, must have as its necessary conditions: a brave increase in public spending on education policies, ensuring access for all levels of education, education systems focusing on pupils and students rather than the imperatives of the markets and strengthening policies to combat youth unemployment.

text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur and my fellow Members for their excellent work. The final text represents a good political compromise on an issue that is crucial for the future of our society, that of the modernisation of education in Europe, where the rate of functional illiteracy is still dramatically high. There are mainly three aspects of the recommendations addressed to the Commission and the Member States that I would like to highlight here. The first concerns the fundamental role of public investment. Without a quality, state-of-the-art education and training system, there can be no real change that is needed today, as never before, to better meet the challenges that the globalised world, technological advances and economic and political crises pose. In line with public investment, there is also the fight against the precariousness of teachers, who are the pillars of the system, who must be guaranteed decent working conditions that no longer mortify their decisive activity, which accompanies students from pre-primary school to university and which ensures that critical and conscious citizens are formed. Finally, the third aspect concerns the increase in functional and media literacy policies. This is something that is too little talked about and which is crucial. I am convinced that we need a common response and a serious medium- and long-term plan, and the text adopted, in this regard, addresses this issue appropriately and outlines good solutions. I would like to close by saying that what makes me most proud of my work is the recognition of the right to education as a fundamental human right, which must be guaranteed to everyone, especially those who are in difficult or disadvantaged situations, such as disabled people or people from difficult backgrounds. I would like to make it clear to everyone, ladies and gentlemen, that no one should fall behind. Really no one.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, in 2000 the Lisbon Strategy claimed to make the European Union the most competitive, dynamic and knowledge-based space. Fourteen years later, the Commission set a golden age of 2020 at which 40% of a generation would be awarded a higher education degree and 85% would have mastered basic knowledge. Weas, the international rankings follow each other and are similar and the numbers are stubborn. For example, the QS ranking, published on 6 June, takes the first university in continental Europe - excluding Switzerland - to 50th place on the basis of the opinion of some 42,000 employers. One can certainly protest against the criteria used, a bit like facing the defeat of a great sportsman - it is good to curse the weather, the freshness of the turf or the bias of the referee. However, Pisa tests, which see certain European regions competing with developing countries, to the dilapidation of our research, as evidenced by the mass exodus of researchers, all confirm that, in fierce global competition, Europe seems to have given up its arms. How could it be otherwise when, with guidelines, the European Union is constantly watering Member States with old-fashioned pedagogical lubies undermining the foundations of centuries-old national traditions. I am thinking of the totem of new technologies in schools, whereas from the OECD to the American Academy of Pediatrics, everyone now recognizes their deleterious effect on academic performance and mental health. Not to mention the over-consumption of pornographic and violent online content or the risks associated with cyber-harassment, the consequences of which on the psychological, emotional and emotional development of young people are sometimes irreversible. I also think of the contempt for the hierarchy between the teacher and the pupil, which resonates with a cruel echo at a time when fear has become a familiar companion for so many teachers in the lost suburbs of the French Republic. But the most striking is the glaring contradiction between the aspiration for excellence and diversity. Thus, while more than 15% of heads of disadvantaged schools in France and Belgium consider diversity of origin as an obstacle to learning, the arrival of an exponential number of migrants in the school systems will be all the more calamitous since it has no consequent effort of assimilation, the requirement of mastery of language giving way to that of multilingualism. Teachers are now being urged to encourage migrants to learn their mother tongue. It is far from the time when cohorts of immigrants came from the far reaches of Poland or Italy, sacrificing their language and identity on the altar of a new homeland of hope and social promotion. Between school and identity divide, the inclusive school dreamed up by Brussels will sow the ferments of levelling down, communitarianism and division.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to congratulate Mrs Krystyna Łybacka on her excellent report. His own-initiative report is certainly one of the most important in this parliamentary term because of the subject he is dealing with. The things that my fellow Members and also the Commissioner have said are right in my statement.  We know about the changes that are taking place. It is a question of taking these changes not as problems, but as challenges, and of addressing them with a truly global approach, involving the whole of education policy. If we want to create a European Area of Education and Training, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity, high-quality universal education is essential. However, this must also become a real political priority for the Member States. It is also essential to provide strong financial support at every level, that is, to schools of all levels, both public and private non-profit, in the knowledge that investing in education is not only and cannot be just an economic imperative, but that in a globalised world it is one of the essential factors for the full development of every person, in all its dimensions.  It is therefore right, on the one hand, to reaffirm the fundamentals, the right to freedom of educational choice for parents, to guarantee all citizens of the Union the learning of basic skills, including, of course, digital skills, equal access to inclusive and quality education and also as a social lift and, on the other hand, to place the emphasis on the so-called modernisation components, which I shall briefly summarise. : educational resources and teaching methods that use the new opportunities, the theme of the disabled, from childhood and not only those who have been treated as an essential element, the so-called triangle of knowledge and the improvement of the link between research and teaching. There would be various things to add. I would like to conclude by recalling the centrality of the figure of the teacher, who must on the one hand be the guarantor and cornerstone for the change in the education system. I believe, however, that what has already emerged today says of the strong will of the whole Parliament to go its own way towards a conclusion that is as shared as possible.

text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is about modernising education! name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Youth unemployment is one of the biggest problems we have in all European societies. Young people are among those most affected by the financial and economic crisis and have fallen out of the labour market only with their temporary contracts. They have been most affected by social exclusion and now they are even starting to vote for the parties that we do not want to see in our societies. The reason for this is very often that they have inadequate education that does not allow them to take hold in the labour market, and that is quite drastic, according to the PISA study: one in five young people have difficulty reading and understanding text. It is therefore essential that we at least tackle the problem at European level and try to help the nation states to do something about it, even if they are the ones who have to do so. Otherwise, we will lose an entire generation and we cannot afford that.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome this report, which brings the word modernisation back to its proper meaning. I come from a country, Italy, where the word modernization associated with education has tasted like a nightmare in the last twenty years: the three "i" by Letizia Moratti, not to mention the good school of Matteo Renzi. Modernisation has meant destruction of the public education system, it has meant dequalification of teachers, it has meant cuts in public spending on schools and schools as education for exploitation. I believe that we need to talk about modernising education, precisely as sexuality education, as an education for differences, and to use a gender perspective in all subjects of education. Teachers must be put back at the centre of the school, as is the case, for example, with LIP, the law of popular initiative for schools. We need to finance a free, free, secular and mass education system.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, despite ever-faster changes in economic and social life, one truth has remained constant over the years: quality education is as crucial as ever for the well-being of individuals and for society as a whole. Providing for it is one of the best investments a society can make. Member States are primarily responsible for their education, and there are wide disparities among them. According to a recent World Bank document, Romania’s education system is failing: 40% of Romanian students are functionally illiterate, and one in five children drop out of school. Adding to this, the skills of the workforce have not kept up with the increasing sophistication of the economy and the switch in exports from labour-intensive to high-technology sectors. To advance from situations such as this, Member States will need EU support to drive reforms in their social and education systems. I am hopeful that through pushes from the Semester process, and with instruments such as the ESF and the SRSP, we will be able to move on together. In this drive, it is essential that we insist on education systems that are truly inclusive and accessible to all people, irrespective of their social, ethnic or linguistic background. I fully agree with the report’s recommendation for Member States to ensure access to mother-tongue education at all levels for pupils from autochthonous minorities. The EU used to request this before accession; it should continue to do so today, especially because we see that many Member States currently pursue policies in full contradiction of their pre-accession promises.

name: Giorgos GRAMMATIKAKIS
text: Mr President, today we are discussing the future of education and how Europe can strengthen its supporting role. I am very pleased that my colleague Mrs Łybacka in the Committee on Culture and Education has seen the problems of education in depth and boldly and has given the right directions on this major European issue. In addition to the usual but important issues, such as closer cooperation between universities and the mobility of professors and students, you will allow me to place particular emphasis on funding targets which should amount to at least 5% of the Member States' GDP by 2025. Europe needs this objective if we want to talk seriously about convergence and economic growth everywhere inclusive. The data can explain very convincingly why this objective is needed: from Romania, which spends only 3% and Greece spending just over 4% – and this with reservations – the distance to 6.5% in Belgium and 7% in Denmark is enormous, and I congratulate these countries. It is therefore clear that in a single market these balances affect the weakest. As the debate on the Union's next multiannual budget has begun, we must claim the investment tools of the next period, which must be sufficiently geared towards the maximum objective of education. Quite rightly, the rapporteur emphasises and pays particular attention to pre-school education. In schools, programs should focus on the needs of the student, not the teacher. The rapporteur's proposal, which I support, to create a European network of universities to make the European education area innovative, vital and attractive, as befits proper education, is also worthwhile.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Mr President, we welcome the approach of the report, which sees schools as autonomous centres for stimulating critical and creative thinking and promoting democratic values and active citizenship. It is our position that education must remain the responsibility of the state and be anthropocentric. The school should remain a fundamental learning environment for developing the potential of young people, providing equal opportunities and equal opportunities for success for all children and young people. At the same time, education must be protected from the imposition of market rules and the interests of multinational companies that institutionalise at-work safety and promote the dismantling of industrial relations. The answer to the huge youth unemployment remains the rupture with neoliberal policies. We need an increase in education spending and an increase in public investment that will seamlessly bring new graduates into the world of work and ensure them decent jobs with full employment rights.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. I consider the issue of modernising education in the EU to be a very important document and I clearly support it. We need to see that the embrace of education and the prioritisation of education challenges are pillars on which Europe's competitiveness can continue to be built. I can fully identify with the basic thesis of the document. These are: emphasising the need for quality education, creating and coordinating the necessary conditions at EU and Member State level, supporting the various elements of cooperation between higher education institutions, the possibility of increasing language and institutional competences, emphasising the importance of lifelong learning and involving a number of modern and innovative elements in educational processes. I am also pleased that the document also pays attention to the teaching of pupils from minorities in their mother tongue. This element is also important because it is the second document this year, which also focuses on the education of minorities at European Parliament level. I would like to recall that on the 7th of February this year the European Parliament voted in favour of the decision 'protecting minorities and prohibiting their discrimination in the EU Member States', which also emphasises that the protection of minorities is also a responsibility at European level. I appreciate that the report, which is otherwise very complex, also supports the promotion of the education and use of regional and minority languages. Since I myself come from an indigenous European minority community, I know that this is of the utmost importance, and I hope that my country, Slovakia, will also heed the recommendations of this document, as well as extra financial support for minority institutions and minority educators.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, our commitment in this report - congratulations to my colleague - is the commitment to the development of the reasoning, reflection and scientific curiosity of our young people. It is a commitment to orientation for professional life with the horizon of entering the world of work. It is an education that we advocate, which must be concerned with informing from the concrete reality of local life, of the country, but also of the international community. The modernisation of education in Europe cannot be induced from the outside. It consists of an inside process, which implies reflection and criticism. The real innovation of education is not only in terms of "more technology", but is in being able to change pedagogical practices and this is not done without teachers. They are the ones who can make education a tool to combat discrimination, particularly gender discrimination. Education was the one that paid the crisis the most. Therefore, continued public financial support should be increased. That is why I do not understand the cuts, the present cuts, in the European Social Fund. Above all we must ensure a teaching that is free, public and free. Modernizing education is getting rid of the manufacturing model and assembly lines that marked the school of the 19th century. Equality is therefore not a minor issue in education, it is a question of justice, it is a question of democracy, it is a question of freedom. If we assume that school can be a place of social reproduction, and that actually happens, then we will be in a position to pursue what unites us the most: the equality of existence and being who we are. The European Union urgently needs to rethink education. This modernisation of European education will be so much faster the more we are able to reflect on the social function of the school and on democracy.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question posed under the "blue card" procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – You said that we need to help children prepare for the labour market in the future, but my question is this: how do you know what skills will be needed by people to enter the labour market in 10 years' time? Does anyone in this House know this? And does any of those people who will decide know this? Where do you get this knowledge from? No one knows what will be needed in 10 years. And please do not say that our goal is equality, your goal is equality. My goal is equality. And education has no right to impose the views of one side of the room on the other side of the room.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Mr President, I regret that you do not know what skills are expected for young people in the European Union in ten years' time. This is very well shaped, for example, by the objectives of the OECD and the Union itself, and therefore it is not difficult, through vocational education, to imagine what the labour market exits will be for young Europeans.  With regard to the question of equality, only those who do not understand education think that education for values, namely equality, cannot be conceived in the classroom.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, if we want to strengthen people's well-being in Europe, build a stable society in different Member States and guarantee an economically successful Europe, we must strengthen the Commission's powers and competences and joint coordination in the field of education policy, because we need significantly more resources and more quality in education. This means that we need to start with teacher training. The level of basic education must be raised in all Member States, as well as in vocational education and training, and resources must be increased.  This is a continuous run internationally, too, where you have to keep up the pace to stay on top. In order to achieve this, and also a common labour market, we need a better model of lifelong learning, better harmonisation of education and training, and also indicators for the European semester of how different Member States have succeeded in their education policy and how resources have been allocated to this.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, I am pleased that this report does not overlook the importance of early childhood education. The evidence is clear that access to high—quality pre-school and early years provision has a positive impact on educational progression and life chances, and that is why it is such a scandal that in the UK the Conservative Government has cut the Early Years budget by GBP 500 million, meaning the door is closing to hundreds of Sure Start children’s centres. Properly funded high-quality early years provision should be the bedrock of our education systems. We also need to see a continued focus on apprenticeships and vocational learning. Those routes are not second-class. They are as important for our economic competitiveness in the future as degrees and PhDs. On Friday, I was at Silverstone, the iconic home of British motor sports, but also the home of the Silverstone University Technical College, equipping young people with the skills and ambition to graduate to high-level apprenticeships at Formula 1 racing teams.  Finally, this report rightly acknowledges that education is also about broadening horizons and encouraging a positive sense of global citizenship. De Montfort University in my constituency is a trailblazer in this, giving its students once in a lifetime opportunities to learn and engage with communities right across the world through its unique DMU Global programme. Let’s not ever forget in this Parliament, our national parliaments, or indeed in regional local government as well, that every young person everywhere has the right, regardless of their background, to achieve their full potential and their aspirations.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all I would like to congratulate my colleague, Mrs Lybacka, on this excellent report and on the work she has done. Together with the New European Skills Agenda, this report represents a comprehensive vision of education and training in Europe. Yes, colleagues, all Member States have full competence over the implementation and development of education systems in their countries. But I believe that we can all agree that a set of sound principles and real-based for a European single market are of great use. I fully support the key priority of the European Pillar of Social Rights to ensure inclusive and high-quality education, training and lifelong learning. However, as a member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I would like to point out that vocational training has not received the same attention and investment as higher education in many Member States. That is why, on this occasion, I would like to raise another alarm to remedy this emergency. Furthermore, as a great supporter of synergies between formal, non-formal and informal education, I call on the Member States to step up efforts to implement the Council Recommendation on the validation of non-formal and informal learning by the end of 2018. I also support the creation of a European area of education, but also of an area of higher education, as presented at the Gothenburg Social Summit in 2017. But I insist that European proposals boost cooperation and avoid any interregional cleavages. Last but not least, Please support the recognition of study periods abroad, as I have proposed with many colleagues in this House.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – First of all, thank you and congratulations to Krystyni Łybacki for such a well-prepared report. In recent years, I, too, have put a lot emphasis on this very crucial importance in my reports, starting with Youth on mobility and others, which is the modernisation of European education systems. I am also pleased that the growing recognition that the quality of education is key, not only in maintaining and lifting economic growth and other economic indicators, but also and above all for ... key in preserving the way of life – European, its culture and values. I am also pleased that European institutions have been paying much more attention in recent years, both with money, education – both with money and through mechanisms that affect the modernisation of education systems in the Member States. Finally, I look forward to participating in the design of the new programme for 2021 to 2027.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, a future—proofed education system should ensure the right of people of all ages and backgrounds, including refugees and migrants, to access quality education in a variety of indoor and outdoor learning environments, in informal, non—formal and lifelong learning, and including subjects such as learning for sustainability, social entrepreneurship and media literacy. In a fast-changing world we are asked to equip learners with skills which do not yet exist, and that’s why transferable and social skills are absolutely key in order to encourage and develop lifelong learning. We also need a strong commitment to training the trainers. The education agenda must not only look at training future workers, but also future active, responsible and open citizens. I believe education must be part of a broader reflection on occupational literacy in the context of growing digitisation and robotisation of European societies. We must focus not only on economic growth, but on learners’ personal development, improved health and well-being, including sex and relationship education for healthy relationships.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the modernisation of education is not merely intentions and theorizations.  It is not possible for a modern school with the public disinvestment that you have imposed since the European semester and structural reforms aimed at privatising and liquidating education and resulting in the dramatic degradation of the school park.  It is not possible a modern school where pedagogy is eclipsed by stuffing 30 students per class in the name of rationalizing financial resources.  It is not possible a modern school in contempt and disrespect for teachers without the tens of thousands who in Portugal were fired during the troika that you imposed or making disappear 9 years, 4 months and 2 days of career to meet economic goals.  A modern school can only be leveraged in free and quality public schools as a guarantor of equality and overcoming economic barriers, alongwith respect for professionals in the sector and their working conditions by valuing wages and reducing working hours.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the education of young people has already been a key concern of all states that wanted to create educated young people, with morals and potential, so that they could ensure the survival of the state and the nation. This need also exists in this day and age. Of course, the requirements have changed and the new requirements require a change in the policy on education and, of course, modernisation of education. We see that due to the increase in costs and tuition fees there is very limited access for students to higher education throughout Europe and especially in Southern Europe and Greece. Also in practice any knowledge of young people has been discredited. Young people are obliged to choose jobs other than their studies, to choose jobs with disparaging working conditions and earnings, or to become unemployed. All of this needs to be addressed. Each State must set up the education of its young people, allocate the necessary funds and, in the end, cooperate at pan-European level. If this is not done, we risk destroying both the present generation and the next generation.

text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I would like to commend both the reporter and the Commission's attitude, there has been a move forward in recent years, because the workers of Europe's future will be given to children from the poorest families, so digitalisation, early child development, which the Commissioner has talked about, and the expansion of services and the elimination of segregation are all among the Commission's objectives, and this is very, very welcome. Therefore, in Hungary, we have tried to launch new programmes that do keep the breakaways in place, and now research shows that children aged 15 and over disappear at the age of six or seven, if the education and crèche system that the Commissioner and the Commission have talked about is really being realised. There is only one point that I would like to add, if you will allow me, now in secondary education, in dual training, we find that companies that will have these children as their workers should be much more involved in both funding and talent management.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, I too want to congratulate the rapporteur and the Commission. It's an extremely important subject. Who can dispute that education has nothing to do with our society, with the modernisation of society, with peace, after all, with the behaviour of citizens in society? That is why I think that we need to think - and we know that it is subsidiarity, but we also need to think at European Union level - how we can modernise education. We have often outdated methods. We must no longer rely on memorization, we must rely on vocation, identify from primary school what skills children have, develop a love of the profession and, of course, we must think about the countryside, Commissioner. What are we doing there? Because teachers don't really go to the countryside, we don't have teachers, we have substitutes, actually unqualified. How to do education in children? And in college, it's already late. And it is also very important to think about how we relate education to the need in the economy, because we are in economic development and we need to take into account the new trades that we need.
