name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, first I would like to congratulate the Commissioner for his good work in this area. It is obviously crucial for us. As everybody knows, education is the way to the future and, if we want to be competitive in Europe, we will have the highest standard of education in the world. As some speakers have said, we have to start with the young, but above all we must start with teachers. As a former teacher myself, I realise how important teaching is. One area where we need to put more emphasis is allowing teachers to have access to continuing professional development (CPD). There is not enough opportunity for them to do that on a professional basis, as distinct from a voluntary basis, and that will make a huge difference. As well as that, we have been putting emphasis in Ireland on the STEM subjects in recent times, and that needs to continue. We especially need to encourage girls into the STEM subjects, and bodies like the voluntary group, CoderDojo, are doing tremendous work to encourage people at a very young age with skills in that area to develop them. So education is the way to the future. The more we can do, the better.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it was very good to hear during the debate that there was broad and strong consensus on the future of education. We share the same ideas and the same objectives. It is a very good starting point for a future collaboration. Digital skills, critical thinking, lifelong learning, skills—oriented education, the role of teachers in the future of education, the quality of education and the role of preschool education – these are the pillars of the future vision of education, and this is a very solid foundation for our future collaboration.  This consensus bears fruit, because we have experienced a spectacular development at European level in education since 2014. Education is now at the top of the EU’s political agenda, and decision-makers and politicians share the ideas of the future European Education Area and the European Universities project. I thank you for your support. I really think that we have to continue this cooperation in the future.  I thank Ms Łybacka for this report, and I look forward to working with you in the future.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Education is a fundamental right. Education is the key to all development. But today's discussion showed that education has another great value. Education can unite us all regardless of political differences. Yes, because the responsibility for educating the next generation lies with each of us regardless of what option we are from, regardless of where we come from, with, of course, educational freedom, while maintaining an even individual learning process. Thank you very much for this discussion. Thank you to all my colleagues. Thank you, Commissioner, for your pro-training activity. I would like to thank the Commission very much for this large number of communications, and I wish all of us that European teachers would respond, as in the last survey, to the question of young people: who do you want to be in the future? The first answer was teacher. And who would you like to be if you couldn't become a teacher? The answer was teacher. So let's take care of the future of education.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, June 12, 2018. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – First of all, I would like to stress that europe's demographic and social challenges, labour market requirements, new technologies, personal preferences and learning needs are driving trends in education. It is important that education systems take these factors into account not only in order to offer quality knowledge, but also to relevant competences, including skills for successful lifelong learning. Technological development and globalisation are creating new challenges. They also cover education systems. The task of education systems in the information society is not only the transfer of knowledge and skills for their application, but also training to develop knowledge, which is a source of competitiveness and the well-being of citizens and the most important economic resources. I welcome the Commission's idea of creating a European education area. However, it should be noted that this area must be consistent with the results achieved so far in the European Higher Education Area and the European Research and Innovation Area. In addition, the European Education Area must receive strong political support from Member States whose joint efforts will provide a new impetus for the development of education, while ensuring respect for the principle of subsidiarity, freedom of education and institutional autonomy. Calls, therefore, on the Member States and regional authorities to invest more in education through the European Union's Structural and Investment Funds, as well as to provide support to teachers and school leaders in modern technologies and by developing pupil-centred teaching methods that ensure a high quality of education, measured by the knowledge gained and acquired skills, creativity and lifelong learning.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. – I would like to reiterate the vital importance of education, not just for nowadays society but also for building a better future for the generations to come. Sustainable development cannot be reached without a solid educational base, adapted to the current framework in order to provide the necessary knowledge and skills to address the contemporary challenges. Digitalisation and common educational platforms have a huge potential, by contributing to the establishment of a modern education, more accessible, available and inclusive, but in order to benefit from their full potential, prevention programmes and awareness raising campaigns on the new issues of cyberbullying must be also integrated within this project. The European education area should be focused on achieving common goals, including ensuring quality education for all. I strongly believe that internal and external collaboration must be enhanced, and the rights of the most vulnerable groups must be promoted, including women’s and girls’ rights. Therefore, a notable increase in the founding of the ERASMUS + programme is essential in order to provide the same opportunities also to students from disfavoured environments and to include more students and teachers, which will result in a better inclusion and more qualified workforce at the European level.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: in writing. – It is not possible to meet the challenges presented to the Union without an education system better adapted to a global, changing and competitive environment. When we talk about "modernizing" education, however, we are not just talking about better use of new technological and digital opportunities. It is also about updating educational methods according to the best scientific evidence. We know that schools are not just "assembly chains" of educational outcomes, but that people, their skills and preferences, count. The education system does not work with raw and docile materials, but with diverse human brains, shaped by millennia of biological evolution and exposed to different social and cultural influences. Early identification of both talent and learning difficulties for students is crucial to reconciling equality and excellence. In this sense, individual differences in the capacities of European students must be studied and taken into account. Education must be at the heart of the European political agenda. Quality education is fundamental to the development of a strong and united Europe, with active citizenship involved in the construction of the European project.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I welcome the report on modernising education in the EU and believe that it is a step forward in ensuring quality education for all Europeans, but also in setting even more ambitious common goals for systemic change at national level. Educational reforms, which must respond not only to the present but also to the future, require political will and strong public support, from their joint preparation to effective implementation involving all stakeholders.  We often focus on the key role of all stakeholders, but I would go even further – to promote the establishment of National Alliances for Quality Education across the EU. Such an example in Bulgaria is the NGO "Education Bulgaria 2030" – an advocacy group of civil, business and public sectors whose mission is to improve the quality of education in the country by 2030. Such associations are vital for the modernisation of education at national level and for constructive and effective dialogue between stakeholders in the common vision of quality education for all.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Education is a key element for fulfilling the economic potential, and a crucial factor for development in the information society. It is vital that education systems take into account the rising social and demographic challenges, as well as Europe’s requirements of the labour market, new technologies, personal preferences and educational needs, which are determining the current directions of changes in education. I strongly believe that in order to deliver high-quality knowledge, while ensuring adequate competences, it is necessary to adapt to these rapid changes. Data has shown that modern technologies can improve the interaction between teachers and students, making the teaching process more effective. This is why I fully endorse this report, which calls for a paradigm shift in teaching. I firmly believe the idea that learning by rote is obsolete and no longer responds to the current needs of society, and this is why it must be replaced by developing skills such as critical and analytical thinking. Moreover, I strongly support that EU Member States must invest at least 2% of their GDP in higher education and give priority to educational programmes, when in cooperation with regional authorities, use national and regional resources and allocate European structural funds.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the brief presentation of Carlos Iturgaiz's report on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, entitled "Towards a Sustainable and Competitive European Aquaculture Sector" 2017/2118(INI) (A8-0186/2018).

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank my colleagues, first of all the Committee on Fisheries, for the contribution of all of them to this report. Ladies and gentlemen, aquaculture in the European Union provides sustainable and high quality products to the consumer, and we can only be proud of our European sector. However, although aquaculture has maintained a sustained pace of growth globally and for half a century, its full potential has not just been unleashed in the European Union. The growth of the sector sometimes runs into several problems. These include the lack of available maritime space for its activities or administrative obstacles, particularly those arising from licensing procedures, or competition on the world market, combined with insufficient consumer information on aquaculture products from third countries, in terms of their quality, environmental footprint, social conditions, fish welfare... or the poor preconceived image that aquaculture sometimes has of citizens, etc., etc. It is true that good initiatives and intentions abound. In 2009, the European Commission issued a communiqué focused on building a sustainable future for aquaculture. And in 2013 he published another on the strategy guidelines for sustainable aquaculture development in the European Union. The new common fisheries policy also aims, inter alia, to give new impetus to aquaculture in the European Union, allocating for its dissemination funding of EUR 1.2 trillion for the period 2014 to 2020. However, implementation did not match the industry's expectations, and initial enthusiasm soon turned into disappointment and defeatism. What do we need to do, then? The strategies proposed by the European Commission remain very relevant today. We must simplify administrative procedures, ensuring sustainable development and aquaculture growth through spatial coordination planning, strengthening aquaculture competences in the European Union or promoting a level playing field for European Union operators and exploiting their competitive advantages. And all of this remains a challenge that must be faced. A large group of scientific advisors recently issued, in a petition by Commissioner Vella, a report entitled 'Food from the oceans: How can more food and biomass be obtained from the oceans without depriving future generations of their benefits?". Your recommendations, ladies and gentlemen, are very relevant, and I share them all completely. A paradigm, as they say, of responsible culture on ocean food must be integrated into general policy agendas at the european and global systems level. And also, as this report says, we must take the development of mariculture in Europe to a higher and more strategic level, through a comprehensive and coordinated political strategy. Well, in short: the problems have been identified, the diagnosis is good and the solutions proposed so far are very relevant. What is needed is a political impetus within a context of mutual respect for the role of each between the institutions of the European Union and the local and regional administrations of the Member States. Thus, the necessary doses of subsidiarity for aquaculture management in the European Union should be mixed with enhanced action at European Union level, setting targets at European Union level, while opting for regionalised objectives tailored to the particularities of each aquaculture branch at local and regional level. I'm done, ladies and gentlemen. We should not forget that the European Parliament has been a co-legislator since 2009 and that any future policy will have to be jointly drawn up by the Council and the European Parliament. And I'm particularly proud of these achievements. I conclude by saying that there are imminent opportunities and appointments that we must not miss in order to give the European Union's saltwater and freshwater aquaculture the place it deserves. And we must also seize the opportunity we are given with this report.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I think this is a vital sector and it had great promise, as has been said by the rapporteur, until recently, when some issues rose and people aren’t as enthusiastic about it now. But the facts are that the growing demand for fish, both in Europe and worldwide, cannot be met by naturally-produced fish. In fact in some cases, the stock is going down, and that has to be managed properly. So aquaculture, managed properly and properly efficient, has a huge role to play. I’ve spoken to people in my own constituency and they’re concerned about lice in relation to aquaculture and its effect on other fish and so forth. So innovation and research has to be done, and then, as a result of that, we should be able to move, to have far more aquaculture than we have now, and that would help to meet the demand that’s there without impacting on other fish resources.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague Carlos Iturgaiz on the consistent report he has produced and for the reflections he has made here. The activities of the blue economy, such as aquaculture, are indeed a priority and their development should be enhanced, in particular in the outermost regions of the European Union that are very dependent on the sea and where most of the time it is not yet developed. In the Azores, where I come from, with the support of EMFF funds, aquaculture projects are being developed. These projects are involving fishermen and are intended to be a complementary activity to fishing, thereby reducing the pressure on resources by finding alternatives for fishermen.  The demand for proteins from the sea and the increase in agricultural production will have to take into account that pressure on wild resources should not be increased. Aquaculture production cannot be sustained by the blind increase in the capture of wild resources, such as small pelagics and krill, which serve as food for the production of species in aquaculture.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, the development of aquaculture has considerable potential yet to be explored. Doing so in a sustainable way requires strong support for scientific research and technological development, a demand far from the daily reality of state laboratories and other financially asphyxiated public institutions. The decrease in dependence on wild fish for feeding cultivated species, improved activity yield, increased feed conversion, cultivation of indigenous species, including freshwater species, algae and herbivore species, along with the decrease in the environmental impacts of the activity, are lines to continue in the development of aquaculture. Investment support is also welcome and necessary. The development of aquaculture should be seen in a logic of complementarity with fisheries, which should especially safeguard small-scale, coastal and artisanal fisheries and favour small and medium-sized enterprises. I say complementarity and no substitution or alternative, not even competition, as some seem to wrongly suggest or point out.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Madam President, the administrative complexity and lack of transparency in the licensing procedures of which the Mr Iturgaiz report is talking about may be an excuse to implement processes, an excuse for complementarity, to replace small-scale fishing and even sustainable aquaculture. I come from a country, Galicia, which lives sustainably in fishing and which, moreover, has its own competences within the shops both in fisheries and seafood cultivation and also in aquaculture. The administrative complexity of the report, hampered by the demands of society, implies that my people stood up against the Galician aquaculture plan that Mr Iturgaiz's party wanted to push and stood up because it would replace our productive activity and therefore we do not want large marine industries, but sustainable fishing. That is why I will vote against this report.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, thank you for giving the floor. I would like to thank the rapporteur for presenting a very good report. In his speech, he emphasized responsible aquaculture several times. The report also contains a concept such as sustainability, and I think that this is really crucial for our future in any sector, but also, of course, in aquaculture. When we see industrial fishing literally plundering our oceans, and many coastal areas no longer actually contain any life, our future and aquaculture are all the more important. We need to support innovation and research, science in this area and support it precisely from European funds.  I think that this has high potential, and I also liked it if my fellow rapporteur also stressed the importance of regional objectives on this very subject. Subsidiarity is necessary, but eu support in these areas is really crucial for our future, I underline this again.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Unfortunately, aquaculture is rarely at the heart of politics, but it is a very important sector, as it will have to make up for the loss of fish due to the tightening and decline of sea fishing catches in the future. The EU should therefore give particular support to both the marine and freshwater aquaculture sectors. Together with my fellow Members, I call on the Commissioner to do everything possible to minimise the level of EU funding in this area after 2020. I would like to draw your attention to the fact that freshwater aquaculture output is one fifth of the whole sector. It is therefore only fair that one fifth of EU aid for aquaculture goes to the freshwater sector. Furthermore, freshwater aquaculture is essentially different from marine aquaculture. In this sector, conservation, feeding or reproduction requires a completely different practice. They should therefore also take these differences into account in accordance with the relevant environmental sustainability standards, with specific rules for freshwater fish farming. It is our joint success that the European Parliament supports these objectives with the Iturgaiz report.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Iturgaiz, and the Committee on Fisheries (PECH) for their work on this comprehensive report. I welcome the fact that your report recognises the importance of developing a sustainable and competitive European aquaculture sector. This report builds on the momentum of the ‘Food from the oceans’ report submitted by the Commission’s High Level Scientific Advice Mechanism. It highlights the fact that aquaculture can and must grow in the future to feed a planet with 10 billion inhabitants. First of all, let me recall that we have already done a lot to create a positive environment for the sustainable development of EU aquaculture. Together with Member States, industry and other stakeholders, the Commission first identified in 2013 the main barriers to growth for EU aquaculture and has been working since to help Member States address them and stimulate growth. The main blueprints for development are the Member States’ multi-annual strategic plans for aquaculture, on which they have made good progress, in particular by developing maritime spacial planning and reforming overly-complicated national laws. The Commission is currently undertaking a mid-term review of the EU’s and Member States’ progress on aquaculture since these plans were established. Our review will be finalised in mid-2019. We are meeting regularly with Member States in the context of the open method of coordination and with stakeholders through the Advisory Aquaculture Council. We have a constructive dialogue with the key players at national level and those involved in production. Your report gives this work an additional political impetus, especially through the links you have established with key players, such as regional authorities and developers, during its preparation. At the initiative of this House, the Commission is also starting a pilot project on trans-national producer organisations, which will hopefully foster cross-border cooperation and increase interactions within the sector. I am proud of the significant funding the EU invests in research and innovation: around EUR 20 million per year under Horizon 2020, as well as in communication to promote sustainable aquaculture in the EU. Under the current EMFF, EUR 1.2 billion, which is approximately 21% of the total EMFF budget, have been allocated directly to the promotion of aquaculture. Your report rightly stresses the need for imported aquaculture products to meet the same standards that EU operators must meet. Let me recall that imported aquaculture products are already subject to strict sanitary requirements and that the European Commission is carrying out regular inspections in third countries to control compliance with EU legislation. Despite the important successes we have already reached together thanks to hard work and commitment, we are fully aware that more has to be done. We need to see even more improvements at administrative level: more reduction of red tape when it comes to licensing new farms – a number of Member States have made clear moves in this direction. More need to follow, and a commitment to simplification and adequate support needs to be taken by the regional authorities who ultimately take the relevant decisions. I share your opinion that support to innovation is needed, and we will support smart ideas and approaches that make the sector more sustainable and more competitive. One way we are working on this is through the launch of a Blue Bioeconomy Forum, which should be operational in the third quarter of 2018, and which will help identify a project pipeline, draft a roadmap for the development of the sector and find new markets and value chains. We are also working on a Blue Economy Investment Platform to support innovative business ideas in the blue economy that have reached the post-research stage, but are not yet ready for full-scale investment. This platform will help mobilise funding from both private and public resources, including the European Fund for Strategic Investment. And of course, there is continued support for aquaculture development in the current and the new EMFF, as well as funding for research through the Horizon 2020 programme. I’m looking forward to continuing to work with you on further promoting aquaculture and developing a competitive and sustainable aquaculture sector in the EU.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, June 12, 2018. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. – This report proposes greater harmonisation in aquaculture and bemoans the un-competitiveness of EU based producers blaming a lack of financial prospects and stability for a lack of growth. I would suggest that growth needs light touch local regulation rather than this proposal which is nothing short of a Soviet style five year plan. The EU is in-competent so should not try to coordinate this and the Commission should not oversee Member States plans. This is just duplication of bureaucracy not a blueprint for growth. The reason the sector is struggling is the existing level of EU regulation making it uncompetitive. The fact that there are two minority opinions is nothing less than a gooey mess. The larger Group obviously being miffed that somebody pointed out the ecological failings contained in the original report. As it happens, I largely support the second minority report as this highlights the destructive nature of battery-farmed fish on the local environment and the impact on inshore fisheries. There is a reason farmed fish have such a bad reputation with consumers! Finally, I can save the Commission some time by explaining what will happen after Brexit. The UK will put its house in order. Maybe you can copy us later?

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: in writing. – We note that, in recent years, the European aquaculture sector has stagnated, unlike aquaculture in other areas which are constantly growing. Evidence of this is that aquaculture production in the EU covers only 10% of domestic fish demand and more than half of such products are imported from third countries. I believe that, in order to reduce the pressure on natural fishing grounds, it would be beneficial for the EU to increase its production in the aquaculture sector.  The Union also needs to develop freshwater aquaculture and inland aquaculture in fenced waters, sectors that represent an opportunity to improve food security and develop rural areas, providing jobs in the poorest rural areas and having an environmentally friendly role in maintaining valuable wetlands and providing a wide range of ecosystem services.  Last but not least, there is a need to simplify and harmonise the procedure at European level for obtaining the necessary documents for this activity, in order to encourage investment in business and thus reduce imports from third countries.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the brief presentation of Norica Nicolaï's report, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the state of recreational fishing in the European Union 2017/2120 (INI) (A8-0191/2018).

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, it is a joy for me to present in the plenary of the European Parliament the first report dedicated to recreational fishing. Sure, recreational fishing is considered a hobby, but it is a hobby of cultural heritage, the traditions of many communities in coastal and island areas. It is an activity that has an economic influence unfortunately easily ignored in our common fishing policies. With regard to marine recreational fishing alone, nine million people are involved and the economic impact of this activity is over EUR 10 billion annually. And as far as freshwater fishing is concerned, which is happening in the vast majority of European countries, more than 25 million European citizens are involved, and the industry associated with this fishing activity is around EUR 25 billion. Sure, it is a subsidiarity area, but it is an area that will play an important role in what we call the 'blue economy' and in the circular economy. Unfortunately, the scientific data at the moment are insufficient for several species of fish. They are present, but it is necessary, for a coherent definition of this activity, to have a solid scientific support. And I call on the Commission to support and stimulate the collection of scientific data on recreational fishing in the Member States in order to have a very clear vision of this activity, in order to have a relatively uniform definition throughout the European Union. Recreational fishing is different in every state, as I said, is part of a cultural given of many communities, but often, for many communities, it is a subsistence fishery and the only source of food for communities in the peripheral areas in particular. The economic activity that can be carried out and which can bring a great deal of jobs to the European Union must also be supported and I call on the European Commission to include recreational fishing among the themes of the year for the EDEN project for sustainable tourism and to initiate us into the COSME fund projects to promote tourism generated by recreational fishing. It is very important to give a chance to diversify economic options in communities that are marginalised and environmentally dependent on this type of fishing. We also call on the European Commission, on the basis of the 2013 definition of the International Maritime Action Operations Council, to try to define this activity clearly in the future fisheries policy; we also ask for financial support for scientific research in the field, for the collection of data in order to determine the level of fish stocks. All this will certainly shape a role of recreational fishing in the common fisheries policy. We believe that the funds in the EMFF must also be for this activity because, at a time of change, with climate challenges, with challenges related to food issues, recreational fishing is a chance not only of recreation, but also of life.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur once again, because she has embarked on a difficult subject. This is the first report on recreational fishing, as has already been said. I would like to start by saying that I am not in favour of any new legislation in this field, and I do not think that the rapporteur has asked for it either, that she has not spoken about it. It is important to me that, in the absence of a uniform definition, it is, of course, possible to arrive at it through a certain procedure, but it is important that we actually promote recreational fishing where it fulfils, above all, that self-supply function, especially in those coastal areas. It is probably also good to support certain financial projects related to this recreational fishery. I understand that it is important that we also achieve certain statistical data and scientific data on this fishery, but I feel that this is somewhere on the border between a hobby and, say, recreational activities, which should probably no longer be regulated or should not be the subject of our dramatic interest.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Madam President, first of all I would also like to congratulate our colleague Norica Nikolai on the report she has produced. Recreational fishing is an important activity throughout the European Union, not only because of the number of people involved or the economic impact, but also in the context of resource management.  The collection of data from creative fishing has to be effective in order to be able to assess its real impact. Only in this way are scientific advice supporting multiannual plans and the management of fisheries resources in general improved. Recreational fishing, as an activity of the blue economy, must be properly developed and closely monitored, particularly in the outermost regions such as the Azores, from which I come. This activity has a relevant social and economic impact in many ports and coastal areas, however there is room to improve its framework in places where there is a need to redirect fishermen to other activities.  Recreational fishing linked to tourism can be an excellent alternative and complementarity giving priority to traditional fishermen. Tourist fishing must respect the tradition of artisanal fisheries.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, recreational fishing understood as fishing for own consumption or leisure can take various forms and use various gears, the most common being line fishing, harpoon, harvesting, and there are also passive methods including nets, traps, pots and longlines. Being increasingly widespread it is important to know better under what conditions this activity is carried out, to obtain more characterisation data, including on the number of fishermen and the most used gears, it is important to assess the impact of the activity, the environmental impact on fish resources and on the marine environment in general, the socio-economic impact in particular on small-scale professional fishing , coastal and artisanal.  It is also important to understand the extent to which we are not dealing with covert professional fishing situations. The protection of small-scale fisheries and its professionals, the creation of conditions to ensure their viability and generational renewal should be a central concern and a priority.

name: Francis ZAMMIT DIMECH
text: – Sur President, qed nitkellmu fuq qasam tas-sajd rikreattiv u interessanti ħafna li anki f'pajjiż żgħir bħal Malta għandek erba' għaqdiet u federazzjoni ddedikati għal dan l-isport. Jien, fil-ġranet li għaddew, kelli l-okkażjoni anki niltaqa' ma' diversi persuni li jipprattikaw is-sajd rikreattiv u rrid naqsam magħkom dak li qed jolqot lilhom. Qed jolqot lilhom pereżempju l-fatt li mhux dej ikollhom il-postijiet meħtieġa biex jipprattikaw l-isport tagħhom, anki permezz ta' kompetizzjonijiet, għaliex il-mollijiet jittieħdu ħafna drabi għal skopijiet purament kuảali. Ibatu wkoll mill-problema, pereżempju tal-ghost fishing, fejn jitħallew xbieki fil-baħar li dawk imbagħad inaqqsu l-ħut li huma jistgħu jaqbdu b'mod sostenibbli. Naħseb li dan huwa settur li għandna nippromwovuh, anki għaliex jista' jorbot ma' qasam kummerảjali bħal turiżmu sostenibbli. Meta rajthom jipprattikaw l-isport, huma jaħdmu verament b'mod li jirrispetta l-ambjent, b'mod partikolari permezz tal-proảedura tal-catch and release.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, debate over the use of the seas and the right of the common people to fish is hardly new. In the UK alone, two million people fish the seas each year, and this report is a welcome development, not least for the context it provides recognising the economic and social contribution of recreational fishing. I want to make three very brief points. First and most importantly, I welcome that this report recognises that the management of the seas exclusively to serve the interests of commercial fishing is both economically and environmentally outdated. Secondly, involving the recreational angling sector’s stakeholders can only lead to better outcomes. Robust processes for dialogue with stakeholders should be developed and enhanced. And thirdly – and I say this with great regret – whatever process is developed for the collective management of the seas that include UK waters after 2020, it would be a great mistake for that process to replicate the mistakes of the past and exclude the recreational angling sector.

name: John HOWARTH
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, first I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ms Nicolai, and the Committee on Fisheries for their report on this very important issue. Providing a comprehensive overview of the state of play of recreational fisheries in the EU and drawing public attention to this topic is extremely useful and necessary. Scientific advice increasingly suggests that recreational fisheries can have an important impact on the state of some stocks. This is, for instance, the case with cod in the Baltic, sea bass in the Atlantic, and eels. In some of these cases, recreational catches could actually be more important than commercial catches. The Commission is monitoring this situation closely and proposes measures for recreational fisheries on a case—by—case basis when science advises that these are needed. To give you some examples: for eels, the EU regulation requires Member States to make estimates of recreational fishing licenses and their catches. For Western Baltic cod and sea bass in the Bay of Biscay, bag limits currently apply to recreational fisheries. For the northern stock of sea bass, only the catch-and-release practice is allowed. Let me mention here the pilot project proposed by Parliament to reinforce the control schemes for recreational catches of sea bass in the Atlantic. The study will evaluate existing control measures and tools, identify the strengths and weaknesses of available solutions, assess the costs and benefits of different options, explore good practices and propose recommendations or guidelines to improve control schemes. More generally, the control regulation requires Member States to monitor recreational catches of stocks, subject to recovery plans, excluding fishing from shore. This implies the establishment of sampling plans and biannual reporting to the Commission. This provision is intended to ensure the appropriate monitoring of recreational fisheries of depleted stocks. Our proposal for the revision of the control regulation, adopted only two weeks ago, goes even further. It acknowledges that recreational fishing can have a significant impact on certain stocks and provides for specific tools allowing an effective control of recreational fisheries by the Member States. For example, we are proposing that Member States establish a registration or licensing system to monitor the number of natural and legal persons involved in recreational fisheries and also to collect data on catches from such fisheries through catch reporting or other appropriate data collection mechanisms. Furthermore, for stocks where EU conservation measures apply to recreational fisheries, the Commission proposes that Member States ensure that all persons involved in recreational fisheries record and send catch declarations electronically to the competent authorities on a daily basis or after each fishing trip. To make this happen, we need solid databases, in particular for stock assessment purposes. The ICES Working Group on Recreational Fisheries Surveys highlighted that data from Member States are still missing, in particular in the Mediterranean. To remedy this, we have now made it compulsory for Member States to provide such data and conduct validation pilot projects within two years of the entry into force of the new EU multiannual programme for data collection. This deadline of two years will expire on 31 December 2018. This is a big step forward, as the conservation of some marine biological resources might indeed require measures on recreational fisheries, and these cannot be properly shaped without reliable data. This being said, the one—size—fits—all approach cannot be applied regarding recreational fisheries. This is an issue that we need to look into on a case—by—case basis, stock by stock, also when preparing proposals for multiannual management plans. While the Baltic MAP does not include provisions on recreational fisheries, both the Western Waters MAP and the MAP for demersal fisheries in the western Mediterranean cover recreational fisheries for stocks, where these have an important impact. This shows that the Commission is actively engaging in the discussion around the impact of recreational fisheries. We are open to your ideas and views to further address this issue with a view to ensuring the sustainability of stocks for future generations and the long—term viability of this segment of the sector. Your report provides precious information and guidance in this respect. Once again, thank you for your efforts and input.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, June 12, 2018.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the Internal Regulation).

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Municipal representatives from the 47 countries of the Council of Europe met in Szeklerland at the invitation of the RMDSZ. We have identified the need to strengthen the relationship between the Council of Europe and the European Union, because we see that the EU is not taking on ET standards on the rights of national minorities. Despite the fact that we have raised it many times here in the European Parliament, the copenhagen dilemma has not been resolved. Accession to the EU requires candidate states to ensure the protection of indigenous minorities, but this obligation will be lifted after accession. In our case, this has resulted in an 11-year period of worsening of the situation of Hungarians in Romania, more frequent law-arrogance and increased anti-Hungarianism. We want et's practice of minority protection to be included in EU law, so we are calling for much closer cooperation between the two organisations.

name: Giuseppe FERRANDINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, eur 1.6 billion has been financed in Italy for 183 water purification operations in the regions of southern Italy. On 15 June, I will be meeting Commissioner Enrico Rolle to draw up a plan which could lead as quickly as possible to a proposal to overcome the infringement procedures imposed on Italy.  I believe, however, that this Parliament and the Commission must also discuss better the polluting parameters between urban discharges and industrial discharges. Failure to revise it risks penalising the municipalities of the Mezzogiorno, crushed by budgetary constraints that do not even allow the management of the ordinary.  We cannot allow the failings of the institutions to fall on the shoulders of european citizens. Such a hypothesis would risk widening the gap even further with the more developed regions, without suggesting any solution to make up for the gap.  I will be working in the coming weeks with questions to the European Commission to give the citizens the answers they are asking for more and more forcefully.

name: Thierry CORNILLET
text: Madam President, I wanted to draw the European Parliament's attention to the case of ghost children. Unicef estimates them at 230 million, of which 95 million are in sub-Saharan Africa, i.e. in partner countries of the European Union. What is a ghost child? It is a child whose birth has not been registered, and therefore it does not exist. He cannot go to school, he cannot have cover, he cannot have official work and therefore of course he is either exploited or begging. So of course, it is not a question of doing it in the place of countries, since the regal prerogative of the civil status belongs to them, but we could help many of them to find solutions and implement them, for example better use of digital, public awareness campaigns or travelling civil registry offices.  Together with a number of colleagues who have been kind enough to join me, we have written to the Commissioner for Development and Humanitarian Action and the President of the Commission asking them to mobilise the unused funds of the EDF or the ICD (development cooperation instrument) so that they can help these countries.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, providing a safe harbor for the more than 600 people sailing in the Aquarius is an obligation under international law and a humanitarian obligation. Wanting to show a heavy hand in the face of these dramatic situations is irresponsible, as well as inconsistent, because 400 of the 629 rescued have been taken over by the Italian Coast Guard, under the orders of the same Government which has denied them landing on their shores. Italy is right when it calls for the involvement of all Member States, but it does not have it when it denies care to shipwreck victims. Celebrating as a victory extending the agony of these people is unacceptable. Victory is saving lives. Today we are once again showing the failure of European migration and asylum policy. It is urgent to agree on new rules that take us away from this selfish, overbearing and uncoordinated image we are giving from Europe. Luckily, today we have Valencia that, like Barcelona and Catalonia, we want to be and we are welcoming Mediterranean lands. That is why the Government of Catalonia has already offered to take in the 600 refugees from the Aquarius.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the European Commission is committed to handing over to the US financial colossus BlackRock the pensions of thousands of Europeans, millions of Europeans. In the language of European bureaucracy says that the aim is to triple the internal market for pension funds to EUR 2.1 trillion. In a translation, it is an attack on universal public social security systems aimed at dismantling them. We have now discovered that senior european commission officials and even European Commissioners, such as Vice-President Dombrovskis, have held compromising meetings with senior BlackRock officials. It is the same gentlemen who, in the country recommendations of the European Semester, do not tire of warning of the unsustainability of public social security and pension systems, which defend and impose pension cuts, as they did in Portugal. We just see why. Even the arguments used appear depressed from the BlackRock argumentary. A company that has been very generous with former European policy makers to whom it recognises good offices. More than explanations we demand that you withdraw the proposal you have submitted. Your hands off our pensions.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Madam President, I wish to draw to the attention of Parliament a fraud by Russian groups targeting EU citizens in Bulgaria and to the inaction of the Bulgarian legal system. EU citizens own flats in the Nestinarka holiday condominium which they use during the holiday season. Last year, Russian nationals exploited gaps in Bulgarian law to set up a property fraud. That law allows formal meetings of owners to set community rules. Some Russian owners convened a non-quorate meeting out of season when most owners were absent. They elected themselves as the new condominium management and imposed a new regime of rules on all owners that enable flats to be seized. After 11 months’ litigation, the Bulgarian courts continue to empower the Russians, even after determining that the claimed meeting was invalid. It is the Commissioners’ responsibility to ensure that justice systems are fit for purpose before and after EU accession. Bulgaria, which holds the presidency, is failing to meet its Treaty obligations. Instead of censure, it will be rewarded with EUR 1.9 billion from the EU budget.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I visited London this weekend and wanted to draw attention to what is happening in the UK at the moment in relation to the Tommy Robinson case. This is not about Parliament interjecting in individual proceedings, because this is obviously unacceptable, although it does not seem scandalous. In this case, on the other hand, the judiciary has gone beyond its powers. It attempts to restrict the right to freedom of expression of bystanders who are not involved in the proceedings. There has been a ban on informing about this process, which is a violation of freedom of expression, civil liberties, transparency and transparency of the process. And even worse, they listened to it. The British media has taken water in their mouths and are not reporting on this process. I am just waiting for Putin to seize the opportunity to reshpher Europe on the application of human rights and freedom of expression. Libertarians in The United Kingdom feel intimidated by left-wing militias and are afraid to admit their views at work. When we talked about the possibility of opening my parliamentary office in London, it turned out that people were afraid to rent a room for fear of militias. This is the UK in 2018.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Last week, members of the National Squad, a Ukrainian nationalist organization, smashed an illegally established Roma camp in a park in Kiev with axes and hammers, and posted it in advance on their Facebook page, and then posted the atrocity on Facebook. This was not the first such case, either in Ukraine or in the rest of Europe. There are Member States, such as Slovakia, where the police act too violently, and there are countries today, such as Sweden, where neo-Nazis can march. I call on the Commission, in the context of Ukraine, not only in the language law, but also in all the other Member States, to act in the interests of the safety and protection of minorities, and I would like to say, in this matter, that it is very important in the new European Roma strategy to compete with this type of hatred. With jobs, the creation of common places, the knowledge of common history, these people who attack and who are attacked, racists and Roma are also unemployed, desperate people whose indifferent hatred of each other can only be challenged by jobs and education.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, 30 June will be Armed Forces Day in the UK. The men and women who serve in our armed forces across the EU are a crucial part of the Union’s defence and security, as well as playing a vital role in peacekeeping around the world. Many British military personnel have been stationed in EU Member States, becoming part of the local community. Some fell in love and married their new-found neighbours. They’ve got children and grandchildren and some have moved back to the UK, taking advantage of European citizenship for their spouses and dependents. But now their right to family life is threatened by Brexit. The UK Government’s careless approach to negotiations has failed to give our service personnel the respect they deserve. People are not bargaining chips. Veterans have served to protect the fundamental values that underpin the European Union. The EU and the UK must now repay that debt and work together to guarantee citizens’ rights to a family life, regardless of the outcome of negotiations.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – I take the floor at an alarming time about the state of democracy in my homeland, the Republic of Bulgaria. The reason for today's speech is the change of the names of 800 localities bearing Turkish-Arabic names in the municipality of Stara Zagora. Let me illustrate to you an example of what I'm talking about. "Ahmed bair" becomes "Antonov rid". Baird can switch to reed, but not Ahmed with Anton. The question is, what is this about? To make them sound more good? I don't think so.  The real reason is to remind turks and Muslims in Bulgaria of the consequences of the dark politics of the communist regime, which left wounds in the souls of hundreds of thousands of Bulgarian citizens. And if for this period the communist regime is responsible, then today's actions bear the imprint of the empowered extreme nationalism, dressed with state power, standing side by side with GERB , a political party that is a member of the European People's Party. Your colleagues are members of this political party. This cannot be European behaviour, much less a country presiding over the Council of the European Union, in the European Year of Cultural Heritage. What an irony. My Movement for Rights and Freedoms party will continue to stand up for democracy and human rights from every stand.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Thank you, Madam President. Is there the Hitler Foundation in Germany? Nein! Is there the Salazar Foundation in Portugal? No! Is there the Mussolini Foundation in Italy? Non signore! But in Spain, yes, there is the Franco Foundation and this foundation makes the apology of fascism and the Spanish dictatorship. Look at this photograph, it's the Pazo de Meirás, heritage stolen from the Galician people, the dictator's summer residence. This Pazo was taken by 19 pacifists who entered peacefully to ask that it be returned to the Galician people because it is now from the dictator's family, the Franco family. The same one that, together with the Franco Foundation, has just denounced the 19 activists for hate crime, among others. It's the world backwards. It is intolerable that in Europe the apology of fascism will still take place. Current President Sánchez has the historic opportunity to outlaw the Franco Foundation.... (Madam President withdraws the floor to the speaker.)

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá deacrachtaí an-bhunúsacha againn leis an gcóras oideachais in 'rinn agus ní mór dúinn é a athrú o bhun go barr. Is léir nach bhfuil an rialtas ag tabhairt tosaíocht dár ndaoine oga maidir le hoideachas. Feicimid páistí gan aon tacaíocht ar fáil dóibh, páistí le riachtanais speisialta, pí a bhfuil deacrachtaí foghlama acu agus pítí as cúlra bocht, agus cén saghas todhchaí atá i ndán dóibh? Tá ciníochas go forleathan agus easpa múinteoirí cáilithe chun déileáil leis. Gan amhras nuair nach bhfuil an stát ag tabhairt ach pinginí suaracha do mhúinteoirí nua-cháilithe, ni haon ionadh nach bhfuil scoláirí ag iarraidh cáilíochtaí múinteoireachta a bhaint amach. Tá easpa múinteoirí Gaeilge ann atá ag déanamh fíor-dhamáiste dár dteanga dhúchasach mar nach bhfuil na múinteoirí sin ar fáil. Mura dtabharfar aghaidh ar infheistíocht cheart a dhéanamh insan gcóras oideachais beidh costas i bhfad níos mó ar an stát amach anseo agus mar sin táim ag glaoch ar an rialtas anois chun an rud ceart a dhéanamh agus an infheistíocht cheart a dhéanamh ionas go bhfuil todhchaí dhearfach ar fáil dár scoláirí anseo amach.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Madam President, a group of people are being unjustly persecuted in the UK. These are British ex-servicemen who served in Northern Ireland. Men in their 60s and 70s are now in danger of being charged with serious criminal offences because of allegations made against them concerning their service decades ago. These men defended us against the cowardly terrorists and murderers of the IRA and sometimes they had to make split-second life and death decisions. The IRA terrorists received an amnesty under the Good Friday Agreement and were able to walk away from their crimes. One now sits in this House. I want to join those calling for an act of Parliament for an amnesty for these ex-servicemen for their alleged historical offences. I also call on anyone who can, to show their support for these men by attending a protest rally at Parliament Square at 11a.m. this Friday, 15 June.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, in 3 days, the festival of all footballers and fans of the sport will begin, the World Cup will begin in Moscow. Football is a beautiful sport – it connects, overcomes barriers. You know the motto "Respect - no to racism", both Messi and Ronaldo say. It is a pity that sports officials do not consider human rights to be a condition for holding top sporting events. It is not the fault of the footballers or us fans, but unfortunately I personally have to boycott this championship, I will not watch it. The Sochi Olympics were followed by the annexation of Crimea, what should we expect after the Moscow Championships?  Ladies and gentlemen, I hope that the championship will still be successful, that the best footballers will win in fair play, and I also believe that freedom and democracy will prevail in Russia one day.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, the European directives are drawn up in order to be implemented by the Member States and go beyond any domestic law. In a number of cases, however, the European Commission finds the legislation ineffective in relation specifically to credit and banking institutions. Continued inefficiency in the implementation of European directives is an incomplete administration of justice. For example, the European Union requires that each Member State ensure that contracts concluded with consumers do not include unfair terms. Banks also have an obligation, but the Member State must also ensure that they are effectively eliminated. Unfortunately, if there is no binding mechanism, as in the case of Cyprus, the European Unfair Terms Directive does not apply.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, reaction to the enlargement strategy at the Council meeting in Sofia has made it perfectly clear that there is enlargement fatigue in the EU. My question is the following. Let’s imagine that we have ‘abracadabra power’ and can make all these countries fulfil the criteria immediately: everything, even more than that. Would they be accepted tomorrow as EU members? If the answer to that question is ‘no’, then the problem is on our side, not on theirs. Therefore, I believe we have to start working in parallel: we, the Commissioner and the others, pushing them to fulfil the criteria simultaneously to shape opinion in the European Union. We have to start talking about what we gain from enlargement: about the well-educated regions, the new markets, creating stability, creating lasting peace, etc. – what our citizens will gain. We have to remind everybody else how the opposition to Spain and Portugal was, and how today these countries are regarded seriously and are respected. So if we do not shape this opinion, we will have serious problems very soon.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Madam President, on 1 June a motion of censure kicked Mariano Rajoy out of the Spanish Government. Corruption cases in the Spanish PP had accumulated, and there had been a conviction. Today there has been another one saying that pp has delinquented. A judge ruled months ago that the PP was a criminal organization.  This has been the Government which has so far been applauded almost enthusiastically by the European institutions when it has persecuted and imprisoned Catalan leaders.  Corruption, the abandonment of refugees are taking the Union into spectacular discredit, while in Spain there are political prisoners and there are exiles who are elected politicians or artists or simple citizens who exercise their democratic rights.  The scandal is capital. Either the European Union reacts, either its laments against dictatorships and injustices in the world will be nothing more than cynical alarides of those who share, but do not fight, the undemocratic principles of fascism and the anti-democratic far right. Now we play this: freedom, justice and democracy.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Madam President, the workers of Gestipack, a subcontractor of the German multinational DHL, complained to the Labour Inspection that the company was paying them a salary below that set out in the collective agreement. The inspection checked the fraudulent action and ordered the company to comply with the agreement. However, the entrepreneur decided to fire the entire staff. Meanwhile, the main company (DHL) has become disensented and has chosen to change the contract without guaranteeing the surrogacy of the workers. This is a clear example of gender discrimination, causing women's wage gaps, consensual and expanded by regressive labour reforms that make it easier for unscrupulous employers to exploit workers and subsequently dismiss them at little cost. The contract and the main company must assume their responsibility for work and social, and immediately correct this situation. We must not look the other way and we will not do so if we believe in real equality. That is why, from here, all our solidarity and support with the gestipack workers.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – Madam President, it is understandable that, in the Coman case, the Court of Justice of the European Union has confirmed that citizens of all EU Member States are equal in the rights given to them by the European Treaties. However, the fact that the concept of spouse required an interpretation of the court is a very bad certificate for this Parliament as a co-creator of Union law.  Every ambiguous term that finds itself in directives and regulations at all costs because of our efforts to compromise is a failure of parliamentaism. It is an invitation to judges to do the work of Members, even though they have not received a mandate from the electorate to do so and do not have to be held accountable for their decisions.  We like to say that the voice of every citizen is important in Europe. However, this must only apply if the directives and regulations use clearly defined terms.

name: Răzvan POPA
text: – Madam President, Romania is a clear supporter of the existence of the Schengen area. However, it has not been granted membership although, according to all assessments, it meets the accession criteria. The European Commission and the European Parliament have repeatedly expressed their support for Romania's accession to the Schengen area. Romania is one of the countries that can strengthen security at the borders of the European Union, and this is one of the clear reasons why it should be part of the Schengen area as soon as possible. Also, the fact that Romania meets the criteria for accession following costly and long-term efforts entitles Romanian citizens and the Romanian economy to benefit from the advantages of membership of the Schengen area. On Wednesday, Parliament will vote on a motion for a resolution on the draft European Council decision showing that Romania and Bulgaria are ready in all respects for accession to the Schengen area. I therefore call on fellow Members to support the draft resolution, which is an additional step for Romania and Bulgaria to become members of the Schengen area as quickly as possible, as is right.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, this month we mark LGBT Pride, an important reminder of the constant struggles of the LGBT+ community. Pride is a time for solidarity against discrimination and against violence, an assertion of dignity and equality rights of LGBT persons. It is a celebration, but most importantly, Pride is political and Pride is protest. Pride should not be a marketing opportunity for multinationals. We cannot afford to have it trivialised and commercialised, especially not when we still have so much unfinished work to do for the LGBT+ community.  Trans people suffer from the highest rates of repetitive violence and hate motivated crimes. Ireland has the second highest prevalence in the EU of hate motivated violence against trans people. Between 2014 and 2016, 62 transgender hate crimes took place on the island of Ireland. So this year, let’s not celebrate Pride by patting ourselves on the back for marriage equality. Let’s make Pride the political struggle it ought to be. Instead of visibility of billion dollar social media networks, let’s have visibility of trans identities.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to comment today on the issue of European solidarity, solidarity between EU Member States. I consider this principle to be crucial, I would even like to say that this principle was at the birth of the EU, and it is on this birth and on the principle of the functioning of the EU that I would like to illustrate the approach of the Czech Government, which, on the contrary, emphasises only the aspect of European unanimity and completely ignores European solidarity. We need European solidarity at a time when we are very difficult, in all Member States, natural disasters, certain tragedies, god forbid terrorism, can happen. It is there that European solidarity has its place everywhere. I would also like to call on the Czech Government not only to be abching on the issue of European unanimity, but also to put more emphasis on European solidarity, which it therefore really lacks.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, in a few weeks’ time the UK’s National Health Service will celebrate its 70th anniversary, and I take this opportunity here in the European Parliament to say thank you. Thank you to the 62 000 NHS staff from other European nations, and indeed all those from across the world. Doctors, nurses, support staff all help make the NHS what it is through their professionalism and skill and their care and compassion every single day, and with Brexit now causing so much uncertainty, it’s now vital that the rights of those EU nationals working in the NHS are protected for the future. So in the 70th year of the NHS, thank you. Thank you to the brilliant NHS staff from the UK, from across Europe, and from right across the world.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, the notice issued by the Commission on 27 February this year sets out measures that must be met to ensure continued interoperability of passenger and freight services through the Channel Tunnel after 29 March 2019. The document recently issued by the UK government, in the course of the BREXIT negotiations, gives us some hope that a sensible conclusion might be reached.  However, it would be hard to blame people in the UK for having no confidence in the current UK Government to get anything right on the railways. My constituents who use Thames Link and those who use northern rail services in other parts of the country, have seen, since the end of May, hundreds of trains cancelled daily – a total and utter failure to reorganise the timetable.  The UK transport Secretary doesn’t seem to accept responsibility and won’t resign. I urge those in the EU who think franchise in UK-style provides any model for how rail should be run, to think again.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: This item on the agenda is closed.
